Subject.descriptiveTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--Pictorial Works|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention--Pictorial works|~|HIV infections--Pictorial works|~|AIDS (Disease)--Pictorial works|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control--Pictorial Works
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS Posters Collection
Description.abstract: Searchable database of digitized AIDS posters from 44 countries. Demonstrates the efforts taken by various countries to promote AIDS awareness and modify risk behaviors.  The physical collection was originally acquired by the History and Special Collections division of the Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library in 2005, and has been expanded through later acquisitions.

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Australia. Dept. of Human Services and Health
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Prevention of AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a painting by an Australian Aboriginal artist, Bronwyn Bancroft, on a black background. A man and a woman, one black and one white, are shown protected within a condom-like enclosure. The female figure includes a glowing image of a womb.|~|Part of the "Everybody's business" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT001.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: The two people are housed in condoms where they are safe from potentially infectious body fluids which are indicated in the outer patterning. The central image shows the continuation of normal lives without HIV infection through the use of condoms. This image also indicates the importance of protecting unborn children from AIDS.

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Caring for people with AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a painting by Australian Aboriginal artist, Bronwyn Bancroft, inside a black border with white text. Painting has a  multi-colored wavy background with two black silhouettes reaching toward each other and the image of an eye in between them.|~|Part of the "Everybody's business" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT002.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: This painting shows that people can safely care for family and friends with AIDS. The waves around the central image suggest the warmth of friendship and love that can greatly benefit the well-being of someone with AIDS. In the center is an eye looking towards the future when a cure will hopefully be found.

Subject.conceptTopic: Indigenous peoples--Australia|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|International Year of the World's Indigenous People (Program)
Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Australian aboriginal painting about AIDS [descriptive]
Description.note: Poster depicts an Australian aboriginal painting by artist Zane Saunders on a yellow background, with four separate views of details of that painting. It suggests that people are at the center of nature's cycle of life, and that we have a duty to protect human life by using condoms.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT003.
Description.inscription: Poster text: This painting depicts the continuing cycle of life and the role all people must play to ensure an AIDS free future. Dragonflies, frogs, birds, butterfly [sic] and the two people reach out to touch the tree of life and hope and the seeds on the shield. The tree's roots turn into water, the mainstay of life.|~|Additional poster text: This poster was commissioned by the National AIDS campaign of the Commonwealth Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services in response to the 1993 International Year for the World's Indigenous Peoples which has as its theme, Indigenous People - a New Partnership.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: People with something in common: we are all HIV positive [inscribed]
Description.note: 10 black and white photographs of twelve individuals, primarily men, some with captions. Poster suggests that we all have things in common with people who are HIV positive, and that we shouldn't discriminate against them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT005.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Someone's boss, someone's son, someone's child, someone's workmate, someone's friend.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AID S [inscribed]
Description.note: Central image in poster is of a naked man and woman embracing while suspended in water inside a clear plastic bag. The rest of the poster consists of a photo montage including pictures of people, medical supplies, typewriter keys against a dark background. Text suggests the need to confront the reality of AIDS without fear or blame.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT006.

Name.creator: National AIDS Council (Papua New Guinea)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: It can happen to anyone-- it can happen to you [inscribed]
Description.note: A woman sits on the floor on a mat, holding an infant in her lap. She faces a window with partially drawn curtains. The room is dark, lit only by a lantern in the corner and dim light from the window. Poster suggests the mother's moment of realization that, not only is she infected, she has also passed the virus on to her infant.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT007.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: "I never thought AIDS would affect my family. I was always faithful to my husband, but he got the virus. It was only when I gave birth that I found out I had the AIDS virus... and now my baby has it too."
Alternate Title.inscribed: Protect yourself from AIDS. Don't have sex, be faithful, or always use a condom

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services|~|Aboriginal Health Workers of Australia (Queensland)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: You don't have to be a queenie to get AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Cartoon depicting a married man who celebrates a "big day" by going to a bar and having unprotected sex with someone with AIDS. On returning home, he infects his wife, and they both get sick. He is shown in a hospital bed. The last frame of the cartoon is a cemetery, with four headstones spelling out the word "AIDS." The poster suggests that it is not only homosexual men who get, and pass on, the AIDS virus.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT008.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: A man has sex with someone who has AIDS. He goes back to his wife, who gets AIDS from him. They all get very, very sick. The end.
Alternate Title.inscribed: You can't cure AIDS, you can only be careful! Use a condom

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: No condom, no way! [inscribed]
Description.note: Multicolored cartoon depicts a man and woman, Australian aborigines, having a conversation on the beach. When the man suggests they get together, the woman asks if he has a condom. The man seems to find the idea of a condom shameful, but the woman insists. The poster suggests that AIDS education is eroding stigmas attached to the use of condoms.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT010.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: You can't cure AIDS, you can only be careful!

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Australian National Council on AIDS|~|National AIDS Campaign (Australia)

Title: Safe sex can be fun [inscribed]
Description.note: Multicolor drawing of a couple, one with an arm around the other's shoulders, both wearing T-shirts reading "Be Safe, Be Sure" and surrounded by the text of the poster.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT011.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: If you kiss, touch, hug, pet or cuddle, you can't get AIDS. Everybody needs to know the facts about safe sex and AIDS. Everybody. And how do you find out? That's easy! Health centres, doctors, youth centres and schools have information on all the facts, and more, that you need to know. If you do have sex, always use a condom.|~|Additional poster text: We do it safely.

Title: Education about AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a painting by an Australian Aboriginal artist, Bronwyn Bancroft, on a black background. Multicolored images of hypodermic needles against a background of other images and silhouettes.|~|Part of the "Everybody's business" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT014.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: This poster represents the need to educate people about needle exchange programs and the importance of safe sex. The small circles house the different groups that are available for counselling and education about AIDS. The flower shapes in the corner represent the spread of good information about AIDS prevention and education.

Title: Wichtigste über AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Large amounts of text on light pink (on left) and light green (on right)background. Background contains very light images of many items: question marks, exclamation points, women, men, etc. Title in large letters in red, across top. Summary of text (which is in German): list going down left side: how HIV gets transmitted; list going down right side: how HIV does NOT get transmitted. Small green (on left) and red (on right) boxes at bottom describe AIDS-Hilfe Salzburg, and the help the organization provides, including contact information.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU003.

Title: STOP AIDS: die Übertragungsweg des AIDS-Erregers geht von... [inscribed]
Description.note: STOP goes across the top in black; AIDS across the bottom. Between the words are nine small illustrations (three rows of three each), mostly enclosed in circles, which depict the various ways HIV can be transmitted. The first 5 illustrations show what NOT to do; these are in red circles with lines through them. The last three show actions which one would NOT transmit HIV.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU008.
Alternate Title.translated: STOP AIDS: transmission of the cause of AIDS happens from...

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Schutzmassnahmen bei Kontakt mit infektiösen Flüssigkeiten [inscribed]
Description.note: Chiefly text in black and white on orange background. Title in large black letters across top; additional text follows, beginning with the information that unbroken skin prevents HIV transmission. Five small, black on white drawings in circles appear down the left side: a walking bomb, a drowning man, man cut in half by scissors, a snail, and a man with a car. Text describes how HIV is and is not transmitted.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU009.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Protective measures when contacting infected liquids
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Die intakte Haut bietet genügend Schutz vor dem Eindringen des HI-Virus.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS braucht Mit-Arbeit [inscribed]
Description.note: Ink drawing. Red human wearing a blue coat, curled up into a ball, sitting in a pool of blood, on a large, outstretched yellow hand. Image is in a style similar to that of the artist Keith Haring. Title across top. Additional information in a box near the lower right.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU014.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS requires working together
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Die Infektion führt in den meisten Fällen in die Isolation. Zum sozialen Tod. Menschen, die mit dem AIDS-Virus infiziert sind, brauchen unsere Hilfe. AIDS kann nicht durch soziale Kontakte übertragen werden. Auch nicht am Arbeitsplatz. Information ist Wissen. Wissen nimmt die Angst. Nur ohne Angst ist es möglich, Menschen mit AIDS am sozialen Leben teilnehmen zu lassen. Mehr darüber im AIDS-Ratgeber für Alle. Erhältlich bei der Österreichischen AIDS-Hilfe (Spendenkonto P.S.K. 7939.600)|~|Translation of additional poster text: Having AIDS or being HIV-positive causes social isolation. People with AIDS or HIV infection need our help. AIDS cannot be caused by casual contact, even at work. Knowledge is power, takes away fear. More information available in a brochure from Österreichische AIDS-Hilfe.

Title: AIDS: der Himmel weint [inscribed]

The hours and dates appear below the figures, the list of sponsors in the lower right hand corner. The title, also in white and black lettering, appears in a blue border at the top of the poster.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU022.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Angst [inscribed]

There is an image that appears to be part of a hand behind the text, and a silhouette of butterfly also appears.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU028.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Fear

Aids Hilfe Tirol. Für das leben mit Aids.|~|Additional translated poster text:  We avoid illness and death, because we hang onto life.  We avoid it, because we have fear.  Meet the fear.  By argument.  AIDS assistance Tirol.  For those living with AIDS.

We help them, by accepting them.  By meeting and integration.  AIDS assistance Tirol.  For those living with AIDS.

He only wants to do it with a condom.  She only want to do it with a condom.  You only want to do it with a condom.  They only want to do it with a condom. Condoms protect against AIDS.

Die Pille schützt sie nicht vor Aids. Die Pille schützt es nicht vor Aids. Die Pille schützt euch nicht vor Aids. Die Pille schützt sie nicht vor Aids.  Das Kondom schützt vor AIDS.|~|Additional translated poster text: AIDS concerns us all. The pill doesn't protect me from AIDS. The pill doesn't protect you from AIDS. Condoms protect against AIDS.

Title: Séduire, ce sont 1000 petits gestes plus 1 [inscribed]
Description.note: A daisy consists of a condom for a center, and its petals are labeled l'écouter, titiller, beaucoup rire, tout goûter, les yeux bandés, désirer.  The cover of the document Permis de Séduire [License to Seduce] is also displayed.  Its design imitates a Permis de Conduire [driver's license], and it contains a condom and instructions on how to use it, as well as information on the modes of transmission of HIV.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE003.
Alternate Title.translated: To seduce, there are a thousand little moves plus one
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Le sida ne se guérit pas encore.  Pensez à vous protéger.  Lors des relations sexuelles, le préservatif peut vous protéger du sida et de maladies sexuellement transmissibles.  De l'info et un préservatif gratuit demandez votre Permis de Séduire. [AIDS is not cured yet. Think about protecting yourself. During sexual intercourse, the condom can protect you from AIDS and sexually-transmitted diseases. For information and a free condom, ask for your "License to Seduce."]

Description.note: Objects commonly found in the workplace are pictured with captions explaining that they are not means for transmission of the AIDS virus: Coffee mug, ashtray, bar of soap, postage stamps, telephone receiver, scissors, awl, screwdriver, pencil, toilet seat, compass, razor knife, first aid kit, bottled water, french fries, a fork in a piece of pie, a pair of partially-full wine glasses, and a hand shake.  Also depicted is a condom in a foil packet.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE008.
Description.inscription: Poster text: A condition de ne pas melanger le sexe et le travail, il n'y a aucun risque de transmission du virus du sida dans l'entreprise.  [If you do not mix sex with work, there is no risk of transmission of the AIDS virus in the workplace]|~|Additional poster text: L'agence de prevention du Sida lutte contre l'exclusion des seropositifs.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Guidelines for a joint labour-management workplace policy on AIDS (from World Health Organization and International Labour Office)
Description.note: Pink background; blue text. Column of centered text with policies; stylized images alternately at right & left margins. Images show: 3 people in a triangle; a test tube; lips with the "No" sign; human with hand over mouth; giant hand with person & "No" sign; 3 people in square with purple border; hand with wrench.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CC002.|~|Date on back of poster, 2003, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: On-site education on AIDS for all workers and management personnel should be provided. Employment or pre-employment testing for HIV antibody is unnecessary and should not be required. Like all medical information, information on whether someone is infected with HIV should be confidential. There should be no obligation for an employee to inform the employer about his or her HIV/AIDS status. HIV infection is not a reason for dismissal. Workers who are HIV infected must be protected from any discrimination or stigmatization. Since HIV infection by itself does not limit fitness to work, no changes in working arrangements are necessary. But if an employee becomes impaired by illness related to HIV, reasonable alternative work arrangements should be made to help the worker stay on the job.

Title: 在校內血液的處理
Alternate Title.other: Zai xiao nei xue ye de chu li
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CC007.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Blood handling in schools
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Blood precautions in schools: To safeguard oneself against contracting blood-borne diseases including AIDS and Hepatitis B, appropriate precautionary measures should be adopted and applied generally. 1. Equip the first aid box with essential items including disposable gloves, cotton wool, gauze and antiseptic for emergency use. 2. Don’t touch blood or wounds with bare hands. 3. Wear disposable gloves when handling wounds or blood-stained materials. 4. Dress all wounds properly after cleaning. 5. If direct contact with blood or body fluids has occurred, wash promptly and thoroughly with soap and water. 6. Clean all blood-stained surfaces with household bleach. 7. Blood-soiled gloves, towels, cotton wool, dressing etc. should be put in plastic bag and sealed for disposal. 8. Handle sharp objects carefully to avoid injury, e.g. 捳椀猀猀漀爀猀Ⰰ 瀀椀渀猀Ⰰ 渀攀攀搀氀攀猀Ⰰ 最氀愀猀猀 椀渀猀琀爀甀洀攀渀琀猀⸀ 㤀⸀ 䄀瘀漀椀搀 琀栀攀 甀猀攀 漀昀 栀甀洀愀渀 戀氀漀漀搀 漀爀 挀攀氀氀 猀愀洀瀀氀攀猀 椀渀 氀愀戀漀爀愀琀漀爀礀 攀砀瀀攀爀椀洀攀渀琀猀⸀ ㄀　⸀ 匀攀攀欀 洀攀搀椀挀愀氀 愀搀瘀椀挀攀 椀渀 挀愀猀攀 漀昀 搀漀甀戀琀⸀ 倀甀瀀椀氀猀 猀栀漀甀氀搀 戀攀 愀搀瘀椀猀攀搀 琀漀 椀渀昀漀爀洀 琀栀攀 琀攀愀挀栀攀爀猀 椀昀 愀渀礀 愀挀挀椀搀攀渀琀猀 漀挀挀甀爀 愀渀搀 栀愀瘀攀 爀攀猀甀氀琀攀搀 椀渀 戀氀攀攀搀椀渀最⸀㰀⼀椀渀猀挀爀椀瀀琀椀漀渀㸀

Title: Montre lui que tu l'aimes en êtant fidèle, en te protègeant, en l'aidant [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a drawing of a couple in traditional attire kneeling and facing each other, holding hands. In the space between their torsos, there is an object that looks like an eye, or possibly a condom, radiating beams of light or energy toward the couple. A black and white border depicts two repeating drawings of Tiki couples. In one, the Tiki couple stands arm in arm; in the other, the couple faces each other, and the male Tiki wears a condom. Poster suggests that couples that respect each other will practice safe sex, and that the Tikis play a protective role by promoting condom use.|~|Part of the "Taua noa" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FP001.
Alternate Title.translated: Show them that you love them by being faithful, by protecting yourself, by helping them
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 1er prix concours de dessins: Robertson Dale, 1er prix concours de slogan "Tauo noa" Apolina Teapiki (1/12/92). Robertson Dale, 23 ans (Bora Bora) allie le traditionnel au moderne. Le couple trés typè avec des tatouages, dans des vêtements traditionnels, révèle une posture respectueuse d'écoutre à l'autre. Au centre, une boule assimilable à une alliance ou à un préservatif, irradie des rayons d'énergie. Tout s'éclaire avec le message écrit. Un clin d'oeil est donné à l'ensemble par une frise de couples de "tikis" protecteurs et porters de préservatifs.

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: France. $b Ministère de la santé publique et de l'assurance maladie|~|Sida Info Service (France)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ce qui suit va vous intéresser. Ça ne parle que de sexe [inscribed]
Description.note: An artistic black and white photograph depicts the buttocks and back of a reclining nude figure (sex indistinguishable) and highlights the sensuous curves of buttocks and back. The figure is reclining with legs toward the left and upper body toward the right of the photograph. In the background are three light rectangles, which are probably windows.  Above the photo, the first two lines of text appear in large black lettering on a lavender background; following are four more lines of text in grey letters on white. Below the photo are 5 more lines of grey-on-white text, followed by the campaign slogan, "Protégez-vous du sida." The logo of the sponsoring ministry appears in the lower right corner.  The message of the text promotes safe sex by poetically talking about mutual exploration of the curves of the body, the pleasures of the eyes and of kissing, and so on.  It concludes by giving a phone number "if you want to talk about it," meaning other ways of practicing safe sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR004.
Alternate Title.translated: The following will interest you. It's about nothing but sex

Title: Sida peut se transmettre de 3 manières, et pas autrement [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster title is in black letters on teal background. Remainder of text is black, white or teal on a rose beige background. In the center is a panel of three small panes, each with a drawing and text to ways in which AIDS is transmitted: having sex without a condom when one person has the AIDS virus; from an infected mother to her baby during pregnancy, at delivery or while nursing; when drug users share needles.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR005.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS can be transmitted in three ways, and no others

A lavender border surrounds the photo on all sides except the top. At the bottom right of the poster, below the text, is shown an unused condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR007.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: When you make love with Sophie, think about protecting Valérie
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Quand on change de partenaire, le préservatif est, bien utilisé, la meilleure protection contre le virus du sida (VIH) et les maladies sexuellement transmissibles (MST).

Title: Protection maximale [inscribed]
Description.note: Photograph of sunglasses, edge of a book, and condom in wrapper, all on the corner of a beach towel on the sand that is weighted down with a rock. Meant to convey protection in the summer sun.  The towel is in blue and brown, with a scallop pattern on the edge.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR008.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Maximum protection
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Bien utilisé, le préservatif est, lors des rapports sexuels, la meilleure protection contre le virus du sida (VIH) et les maladies sexuellement transmissibles (MST). Vérifiez que la marque NF figure sur l'emballage: cela signifie que les préservatifs ont été soumis aux contrôles de qualité de la norme française, l'une des plus strictes d'Europe. Une notice d'utilisation est délivrée dans chaque boîte. Consultez-la. Enfin, en cas de sécheresse vaginale et pour toute pénétration anale, pour éviter tout risque de rupture du préservatif, utilisez également un gel à base d'eau, en vente dans les pharmacies et dans certaines grandes surfaces. Pour en parler, Sida Info Service au 05.36.66.36. Protégez-vous du sida.

Title: Vivre d'amour et de gel à base d'eau [inscribed]
Description.note: Two rows of four black and white drawings each, with text, illustrating step-by-step instructions for opening a condom wrapper, correctly putting on the condom, applying the gel, engaging in anal sex, removing the condom after ejaculation, and disposing of the condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR009.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Live on love and water-based gel
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Bien utilisé, le préservatif, associé à un gel exclusivement à base d'eau, est un moyen efficace de se protéger du virus du sida (VIH) et des maladies sexuellement transmissibles (MST) lors d'une pénétration anale entre hommes. Les gels à base d'eau sont en vente dans les pharmacies, certains grandes surfaces et sex-shops. Voici quelques conseils pratiques pour une efficacité optimale de ces produits.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous

The image depicts someone calling this help line.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR010.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Title: Mine de rien, on trouve des lieux de prévention du sida à tous les coins de rue [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Protégez-vous du sida. Protégez les autres
Description.note: Text appears over a photograph of a Paris street. On the left, sticking out from a building, is a lighted "plus" sign, representing a pharmacy.  The poster stresses the importance of pharmacies as places to obtain condoms and new syringes. Pharmacists are available to listen and offer advice and support.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR012.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: You may not have noticed, but there are AIDS prevention locations on every street corner
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: En un an les pharmacies ont delivré 52 millions de préservatifs, 1.8 million de Stéribox (R) et plus de 10 millions de seringues, ce qui les place en première ligne de la tutte contre le sida. Aujourd'hui les pharmaciens mettent à la disposition des usagers de drogues des seringues vendues à l'unité. C'est important, car une seringue ne doit servir qu'une fois et ne doit pas être partagée. Le pharmacien sait aussi accueillir, écouter, conseiller et orienter: il est proche de vous.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Votre pharmacien, acteur de la prévention du sida

Title: Vous le trouvez craquant? Dites-vous que ses "ex" aussi. [inscribed]
Description.note: To the right of the text is a photograph of an attractive young caucasian man with a bare, muscular torso, hands stuffed into the pockets of his jeans. He is smiling sweetly and seductively into the face of the viewer.  The message is, when you suddenly fall for someone and want to make love, do not forget to use a condom for protection, even from the very first time. Protect yourselves from AIDS. A colored picture of a condom is inset at the bottom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR016.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Do you find him sexy and seductive? His "ex" probably did too.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: L'été est le moment propice au coup de foudre. Parler du préservatif ensemble et l'utiliser systématiquement, permettent de se protéger. Contempler un homme, lui sussurer des mots, sortir avec lui, ne dit rien de son passé. Alors si vous craquez, n'oubliez pas le préservatif et ce, dès la première fois. Pour en parler, Sida Info Service au 05.36.66.36.

Title: Heu-reux: Anne et Philippe se réveillent tranquillement [inscribed]
Description.note: The top portion of the poster is a photograph of a man and a woman, standing on a balcony, with a house opposite in the background.  They hold bowls of steaming breakfast food. One sees the woman's face looking affectionately at the man, but his face cannot be seen. They are casually dressed, having just awakened from a night of protected sex.  The text promotes use of condoms coated with water-based gel for comfort and for protection of the condom against breakage. A colored picture of a condom is inset at the bottom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR017.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Cette nuit, ils ont fait l'amour en se protégeant. Ils se servent d'un préservatif lubrifié. Ils ajoutent un gel à base d'eau en cas de séecheresse vaginale pour ne pas gêner Anne et pour toute pénétration anale, afin d'évite tout risque de rupture du préservatif. Ces gels à base d'eau sont en vente dans les pharmacies et certaines grandes surfaces. Pour en parler, Sida Info Service au 05.36.66.36.
Alternate Title.descriptive: Happy: Anne and Philippe wake up quietly

They are looking affectionately at each other and smiling. Casually dressed, they have just awakened from a night of adventurous and protected sex. The text promotes use of condoms coated with water-based gel for comfort and for protection of the condom against breakage. A colored picture of a condom is inset at the bottom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR018.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Happy: Eric and Christopher live together

Pour toute pénétration, ils emploient un préservatif associé à un gel à base d'eau, afin d'éviter tout risque de rupture du préservativ. Ces gels à base d'eau sone en vente dans les pharmacies et dans certaines grandes surfaces. Pour en parler, Ecoute Gaie au (1) 44.93.01.02 et Sida Info Service au 05.36.66.36.

Title: Bien assurer la première fois, c'est simple comme lire une B.D. [inscribed]
Description.note: To the left of the text is a four-image panel, arranged vertically, with drawings illustrating the steps in using a condom: place it on the end of the erect penis, smooth it all the way down, and remove it when finished.  The message is directed to young people who are sexually inexperienced, and seeks to reassure them that using a condom every time provides good protection. The comic-strip style of the illustrations emphasizes how easy it is to learn to use a condom and adopt this as a habit. A colored picture of a condom is inset at the bottom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR019.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: To be well-insured the first time is as simple as reading a comic strip
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Cet été, ce sera peut-être la première fois. L'inexpérience, l'émotion, la hâte, la peur de ne pas assurer peuvent décontenancer lors d'un premier rapport sexuel.  Mais pour assurer, on n'est pas obligé de battre des records. En prenant son temps, en parlant ensemble, en essayant le préservatif tout seul avant, on est plus rassuré...

Contempler une fille, lui sussurer des mots, sortir avec elle, ne dit rien de son passé. Alors si vous craquez, n'oubliez pas le préservatif et ce, dès la première fois. Title: Vous utilisez toujours une seringue neuve pour un shoot. Vous voilà donc à moitié protégé [inscribed]
Description.note: To the left of the text is a photograph of a syringe. Below and to the right of the text is a photo of a new condom, which appears in conjunction with the phrase "Protégez-vous du sida." The poster promotes the use of new syringes for every injection, and use of condoms, by explaining that both of these methods prevent transmission of the AIDS virus, other sexually transmitted diseases and hepatitis. Hotline services and telephone numbers are given. A colored picture of a condom is inset at the bottom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR021.
Alternate Title.translated: You always use a new syringe to shoot up.  So there you are, half protected

En utilisant une seringue neuve à chaque injection ou en ne la partageant pas, vous vous protégez de la transmission du virus du sida (VIH) par voie sanguine....

Title: Nouveaux traitements contre le sida? Je sais qu'ils sont plus efficaces mais je ne veux pas entendre parler de maladie [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous
Description.note: Part of: "Sida. Aujourd'hui on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous" campaign [AIDS. Today, we can do a lot. But nothing without you]|~|At the top is a color photograph of a young man which shows his head, shoulders and arms; his palms are pressed tightly against his ears and his facial expression suggest a refusal to hear anything. His shirt is yellow and open at the collar. In the background is a partly cloudy sky. The poster promotes the fact that effective medical treatment will slow the growth of HIV infections; these medications are synonymous with hope much more than sickness. It encourages young men to consult with a physician.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR022.
Alternate Title.translated: New treatments against AIDS? I know they're more effective, but I don't want to hear any talk about sickness
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: On peut se savoir atteint par le virus du sida et ne pass se résoudre à entreprendre un traitement.  Pas facile, alors qu'on se sent parfaitement bien, de prendre des médicaments qui rappellent la réalité de la maladie et la rendent visible...|~|Along the left side in small type: AUSTRALIE R.C.S. Nanterre B318 827 102 Réf.: 13-98 251-A

Poster contrasts the length of time it takes to claim a championship with the length of time it takes for AIDS to claim another person.|~|Part of "Le Sida en on meurt encore" campaign [AIDS, people still die from it]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR023.
Alternate Title.translated: One European championship every four years
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 1 personne contaminée par le virus de Sida toutes les 2 heures en France|~|Translation of additional poster text: One person contaminated by the AIDS virus every two hours in France.

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: France. Ministère de l'emploi et de la solidarité|~|France. Ministère de la santé publique|~|Sida Info Service (France)

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Procedure exceptionnelle, en l’absence de seringues neuves uniquement [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous
Description.note: Depicts a syringe container, with instructions on how to disinfect them for re-use. Poster explains that these procedures should only be followed in the absence of clean, new syringes.|~|Part of: "Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous" campaign. [AIDS, today we can do a lot. But nothing without you]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR024.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Exceptional procedure, only in the absence of new syringes
Description.inscription: Additonal poster text: A défaut de seringues neuves uniquement. Désinfection des seringues usagées à l’eau de Javel. Réduit les risques de contamination par le virus du sida et des hépatites mais ne les élimine pas totalement. Lavez abondamment la seringue a l’eau courante des que possible apres l’injection, puis desinfectez...

Personal or Corporate Name.funder: Comité français d'éducation pour la santé|~|France. Ministère de l'emploi et de la solidarité|~|Bouches-du-Rhône (France). Conseil général|~|Conseil régional Provence-Alpes-Côte-d'Azur
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Dimanche matin à Marseille [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous
Description.note: Photo showing a wooden floor with a bag. Spilling from the bag are artifacts: plaid shorts, a billfold, pills, a subscription for AZT, and three photographs. The photo evokes scenes from the motion picture Dimanche matin à Marseille, which consists of three film shorts named after the main characters in each: Renaud, Catherine, Béranger. The film shorts cover episodes from the lives of three people whose lives have been touched by AIDS.|~|Credits: Mario Fanfani (director); Jean-Pierre Bacri, Christiane Cohendy, Charles Berling, Fatiha Cheriguene, Sara Louis, Jean-Benoît Terral.|~|Part of: "Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous" campaign [AIDS. Today, we can do a lot. But nothing without you]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR025.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Sunday morning in Marseille
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDES-Provence et HB Productions present ... Dimanche matin à Marseille, 3 courts métrages de Mario Fanfani. Avec le soutien financier du Ministère de l’emploi et de la solidarité--Secrétariat d’état à la santé; du Comité français d’éducation pour la santé; de la DDASS des Bouches-du-Rhône; du Conseil Regional Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur; du Conseil Général des Bouches-du-Rhône, de la ville de Marseille; de l’Assistance Publique-Hôpitaux de Marseille.

Poster encourages individuals to become active in the fight against AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR026.

Title: Ruban disparaît? Pas le Sida [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous
Description.note: Depicts a column of four AIDS ribbons against a white background, a progression from bright red fading to nearly-white (or transparent). Suggests that while the AIDS remembrance ribbon may fade away, AIDS remains. Encourages AIDS awareness.|~|Part of: "Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous" campaign [AIDS. Today, a lot can be done--but nothing without you]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR027.

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nuit était belle, le ciel étoilé et Shéhérazade sortit un preservatif [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Pour que votre histoire d’amour reste un conte de fées
Description.note: Cartoon picture in the style of the 1992 Walt Disney film, Aladdin. Depicts a night scene, with Sheherazade on the balcony of a room having sex with the prince. In her hand is a condom. On the floor lies the book, Les mille et une nuits.|~|Part of: "Pour que votre histoire d’amour reste un conte de fées" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR028.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Night was beautiful, the sky was starry, and Sheherazade took out a condom
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Car c'était une jeune fille moderne qui savait parfaitement que le corps d'une femme est huit fois plus réceptif au virus du sida. Shéhérazade était de nature joyeuse, mais elle refusait de plaisanter avec ces choses là. The prince aprécia chez elle ce trait de charactère... Si comme Shéhérazade vous souhaiter engager le dialogue, parler de protection avec votre partenaire. SIDA Info Service vous écouter et vous conseille.

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Douce Peau d'Ane dit: Avant d'aller plus loins, mon prince, prenons des précautions [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Pour que votre histoire d’amour reste un conte de fées
Description.note: A cartoon parody of a scene from the Charles Perrault fairy tale, Donkey-Skin. Shows the kitchen table in a rustic cabin, where Donkey-Skin is about to have sex with the prince. The text encourages women to practice safe sex.|~|Part of: "Pour que votre histoire d’amour reste un conte de fées" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR029.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Sweet Donkey-Skin says, 'Before going any farther, my prince, let's take some precautions'
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Peau d'Ane ne hésita pas à mettre elle-même un préservatif à son prince car elle était bien consciente que le corps d'une femme est huit fois plus receptif au virus de sida. ... Si comme Peau d'Ane vous souhaiter engager le dialogue, parler de protection avec votre partenaire.

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Comité français d'éducation pour la santé

Title: C'est parce qu'il y a des raisons d'espérer qu'il faut continuer. Restons unis dans l'espoir [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photo showing the faces of a young man and woman. The man's head is bowed; the woman faces the camera. Neither is smiling. in the foreground, against a blue background, is the poster title. In the lower right corner is a red AIDS ribbon. Encourages unity in the struggle against AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR030.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: It is because there are reasons for hope that we must go on. Let us remain united in hope
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 1er Décembre, Journée mondiale de lutte contre le sida|~|Translation of additional poster text: Produced in conjunction with World AIDS Day, December 1st.

Title: Après tout, c'était une bonne soirée [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Protégez vous du sida. Protégez les autres
Description.note: Poster promotes condom use to prevent transmission of the HIV virus.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR031.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Part of the "Protégez vous du sida. Protégez les autres" campaign.
Alternate Title.translated: After all, it was a good night
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Pour une fois, je peux me passer de préservatif; ça ne va pas me tuer. Vous pensez avoir autant de vies que sur votre console de jeux? Protégez-vous du sida; protégez les autres.|~|Translation of additional poster text: For one time, I could forget the condom; it wouldn't kill me. Do you think you have as many lives as in your video game? Protect yourself from AIDS; protect others.

Title: C'est si important d'être là [inscribed]

Poster highlights the importance of having compassion for people with AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR032.

Title: Demain, 3 minutes de soleil en moins [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Demain, trois minutes de soleil en moins|~|Sida. On en meurt encore
Description.note: Depicts the arm & foot of someone sitting in the foreground; television with weather map of France is in the background, showing pictures of clouds over most of the cities. Poster compares a weather forecast with AIDS statistics, implying that just as people pay attention to the state of the weather, they should also pay attention to the status of AIDS.|~|Part of: "Sida. On en meurt encore" campaign [AIDS. People still die from it]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR033.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Tomorrow, three minutes less sun
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Demain, 12 personnes de plus contaminées par le virus de sida en France. [Tomorrow, 12 more people contaminated with the AIDS virus in France.]

Title: Sida Info Service, 0 800 840 800 [inscribed]
Description.note: Depicts red telephone cord looped to look like an AIDS ribbon. Promotes the use of the Sida Info Service for information, support, & counseling.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR034.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Vous écouter, vous soutenir, vous orienter. 24 h sur 24, des femmes et des hommes vous répondent. In lower right corner of poster: "Stratéous."

Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Patients|~|AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|Awareness|~|Dead persons|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.designer: Avicenne, J.|~|Boullangier, C.|~|Lavigne, D.|~|Maurisson, G.|~|Negroni, Barbara de
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: New calendar project, calendar of people who lived with AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Bottom half of poster shows calendar styled like a day planner, with name of each month highlighted in red, and with first names of AIDS victims in black. The calendar is shaped like the letter T, and forms the beginning of the word "time." Invites readers to participate in the calendar project.|~|Presented in conjunction with the XI International Conference on AIDS, Vancouver, 1996; updated in 1999. First model of the calendar was published in issue no. 23 (Jan. 1996) of 'Sida Tout Va Bien,' the newsletter of the Association positifs.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR035.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text, located on top half of poster, describing the development of the calendar: In order not to forget the people who have fought AIDS, to show the spread of the epidemic and to warn as many people as possible, particularly those who still feel that AIDS does not concern them, we wish to create a new calendar, adding to the one already in existence, where each day is given the first name of a person who died of AIDS....

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sol En Si, SOLlidarité ENfants SIda [inscribed]
Description.note: Yellow and orange background with black text. Color illustration of part of a house and the sun. Promotes the services of Sol En Si, a support group created in 1990 to help families with children who are HIV positive or have AIDS. Poster lists telephone numbers for Sol En Si sites in Paris, Bobigny, Bois Colombes, Marseille, Nice and Cayenne.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR036.
Alternate Title.translated: Sol En Si, Solidarity [for] Children [with] AIDS
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Association de soutien aux familles séropositives ou touchées par le Sida. [Support group for HIV-positive families or families affected by AIDS.]

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Parce que c’est souvent difficile d’en parler … Sida Info Service, 24 heures, 7 jours [inscribed]
Description.note: White and blue background with black text. Depicts pairs of blue and orange telephones linked by black or grey telephone cords. Advertises the hotline service provided by Sida Info Service.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR037.
Alternate Title.translated: Because it is often difficult to talk about it ... Sida Info Service, 24/7
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: écouter, informer, orienter, soutenir. Appel anonyme et gratuit. [Listen, inform, direct, support. Calling is anonymous and free.]

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: T’as rien oublie? [inscribed]
Description.note: Blue-green background with black text. Cartoon of whistling seal holding hat shaped like a condom. Humorous reminder to take precautions when visiting a sauna for sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR038.
Alternate Title.translated: Have you forgotten anything?
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Le sauna c’est le repos et la détente, profitons-en, en toute sécurité. Bon Sauna !|~|Translation of additional poster text: The sauna means rest and relaxation; let's benefit from it in complete safety. Happy Sauna!

Description.note: Pink background with black and white text. Picture of a night scene, a tent among trees; silhouette of couple seated in tent. Superimposed on picture is a column of text representing their conversation their tastes in music and dancing, with font of decreasing size. Poster humorously suggests that rather than talking about favorite dance styles, the couple should discuss safe sex.|~|Part of: "Sida. Aujourd'hui on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous" campaign [AIDS. Today, we can do a lot. But nothing without you]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Alternate Title.translated: And the condom… What are you waiting for to talk about it?
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Pour moi, y'a que la techno pour danser.--Attends la techno c'est cool mais faudrait pas oublier la transe. --Mais non, la transe c'est naze, à la rigeur le trip hop --Quoi! le trip hop? c'est juste du hardcore vaguement mélodique...

Title: Jai deux amours, je les protège [inscribed]

The bottom photograph depicts the same man walking the same dog at night, and approaching a man who is sitting on a park bench. Poster suggests the importance of condom use to prevent transmission of HIV/AIDS. Phone number for AIDS hotline, SIDA Info Service, also appears.|~|Part of the "Protégez vous du sida. Protégez les autres" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR048.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: He is handsome, he is single, he is in agreement
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Vous vous dites que vous feriez bien l'amour avec lui; si vous lui proposez une capote, vous avez peur de passer à côté. Il se dit qu'il ferait bien l'amour avec vous, mais s'il vous propose une capote il a peur de passer à côté.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Elle a des jambes de 2 mètres de long; elle ressemble étrangement un top model, et étrangement, elle est d'accord [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Protégez vous du sida. Protégez les autres
Description.note: A red-tinted photograph of an attractive woman, with white text, and a photograph of a condom and wrapper at the bottom. Poster promotes the use of condoms to prevent HIV/AIDS transmission, and also provides a hotline number for SIDA Info Service.|~|Part of the "Protégez vous du sida. Protégez les autres" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR049.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: She has legs 2 meters long, she has an odd resemblance to a supermodel, and oddly she is available
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: C'est clair qu'en lui parlant de capote elle va changer d'avis. Vous pensez vraiment que parce qu'elle est belle, elle est stupide? [It's clear that if you mention a condom she will change her mind. Do you really think that because she is beautiful she is stupid?]

Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR051.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR052.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR054.

Title: Hey pote, passe-moi une capote! Toujour avec un gel à base d'eau [inscribed]

The poster targets young gay men and encourages the use of condoms and water-based lubricants to prevent the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR055.
Alternate Title.translated: Hey pal, pass me a condom! Always with a water-based lubricant

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sida Info Service : nous avons le devoir de réponse [inscribed]
Description.note: Eight black and white portraits: interracial couple; woman with her hair tied back wearing a cardigan; man wearing a black sports coat; gay male couple; man wearing a checkered oxford; middle aged couple; woman wearing a jean-jacket; man wearing a leather jacket with a hoop earring in one ear and a stud in the other. Poster provides the phone number for a 24-hour AIDS hotline, Sida Info Service, and suggests it as a resource for questions about HIV and AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR056.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS Info Service : we have a duty to respond

Title: Et le préservatif, vous attendez quoi pour en parler? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a color photograph of a man and woman leaning on the hood of a car on a cliff and looking out over the ocean. Additional text indicates that they are talking about the relationship of individual countries to the European Union. Poster suggests that it is more important to talk about condoms and safe sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR058.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: And the condom, why are you waiting to speak about it?

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Virus du sida ne se transmet pas en pénétrant dans le bureau d'une collègue [inscribed]
Description.note: Depicts a door handle covered by a condom. Poster addresses a misperception about the transmission of the AIDS virus. Poster suggests through the image (suggestive representation of a penis) and text (penetrating) the actual mode of transmission of the AIDS virus through sex, and the importance of using a condom as protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR059.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS virus is not transmitted by penetrating the office of a female colleague

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Virus du sida ne se transmet pas en suçant le stylo d'un collègue [inscribed]
Description.note: Depicts pens covered with condoms inside a pencil holder. Poster addresses a misperception about the transmission of the AIDS virus. Poster suggests through the images (suggestive representations of penises) and text (sucking) the actual mode of transmission of the AIDS virus through sex, and the importance of using a condom as protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR060.
Alternate Title.descriptive: AIDS virus is not transmitted by sucking a colleague's pen

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Virus du sida ne se transmet pas en empoignant le combiné d'un collègue [inscribed]

Alternate Title.descriptive: AIDS virus is not trasmitted by using the telephone receiver of a colleague

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Vous avez des doutes... Des reponses pour y voir plus clair [inscribed]

It promotes the Sida Info Service in France which provides 24/7 information services. A red telephone cord in the shape of an AIDS ribbon is placed on top of the hotline number. The Services are confidential, anonymous, and free.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR062.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 0 8000 840 800, Sida Info Service.

Title: Who will make war against AIDS? [inscribed]

Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR064.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ceci ne transmet pas le virus du sida [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster presents a sequence of illustrations which show how HIV cannot be transmitted: man shaking hands; man laying on a couch with his cat and swatting a fly; man on a ladder in a pool wearing a swim cap with a fish next to him; man covered in soap suds standing next to a hanger and washing machine; man exiting a public restroom; man holding a hammer jumping to reach a nail; two children playing with blocks; man drinking from a public water fountain; man running with flowers in his hand for a hospital visit; man sitting at a table with a plate in front of him holding a large knife and fork; man and woman hugging and kissing; man surrounded by two large telephone receivers; doctor examining a patient; man donating blood.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR072.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Text promotes HIV testing as a matter of individual responsibility, and gives information about when an HIV test is, or is not, obligatory.

Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Faire volontairement un test de dépistage du VIH est un comportement responsable. En France, le test n'est pas obligatoire sauf à l'occasion des dons de sang, de sperme ou d'organes. On ne peut donc pas l'exiger de vous. [Voluntarily taking an HIV test is responsible behavior. In France, the test isn't mandatory except when donating blood, sperm or organs. It is not otherwise required of you.]

Die Broschüre können Sie bei der Bundeszentrale für gesundheitliche Aufklärung, 51101 Köln, anfordern. [The most important information on AIDS is covered on this poster. It covers the illness and its process as well as topics " which we should know about AIDS." It answers your most important questions. The pamphlet can be requested at the Federal Center for Health Education.]

Illustrated with a photograph of a naked man with his back showing.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW037b.
Alternate Title.translated: Information about safe sex

Subject.conceptTopic: Hepatitis A|~|Hepatitis C|~|Vaccinations|~|Condoms|~|Hepatitis, Viral--Prevention|~|Hepatitis B|~|Hepatitis, Viral--Transmission
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Poster of two nude men facing each other having sexual contact
Description.note: Poster announces that sexual behavior can lead to a Hepatitis disease. Capital letters A,B,and C represents Hepatitis A,B,and C clarifying that there are three different viruses.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW038.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Gegen Hepatitis A und Hepatitis B kann man sich impfen lassen. Übertragungsrisiko bei Hepatitis C kann mit Kondomen gemindert werden.[One can vaccinate himself against Hepatitis A and Hepatitis B. The transmission risk in Hepatitis C can be decreased by using a condom.]

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|World AIDS Day|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS Ist Auch Männersache
Description.note: Poster shows four various pictures of condoms, A hand lifting weights, a lipstick, and four Teddy bears. Unprotected sex can cause loved ones to get involved in the chain of AIDS. The logo of "Gib AIDS Keine Chance," Give AIDS no chance, represents a campaign for the federal center of health clearing-up.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW039.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS is also a Man's business
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Gesundheit, Sexualität, Familie, Prävention, Kondome, Weltaidstag 1. Dezember [Health, Sexuality, Family, Prevention, Condom, World AIDS Day December 1]

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Condoms protect against HIV not Syphilis
Description.note: Poster shows a topless male figure standing in the dark. Because symptoms of Syphilis are unnoticed, it is similar to when a person is left in the dark.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW040.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: info+ Bei Menschen mit HIV gelten besondere Dosierungs- empfehlungen für die Syphilis-behandlung, außerdem schreitet bei ihnen eine unbehandelte infektion schneller fort- bei einer Syphilisdiagnose ist daher ein HIV-Test sinnvoll. [For people with HIV, special dosage is recommended to treat Syphilis. It is a step closer to treating the infection quickly. When diagnosed with Syphilis, an HIV test is useful.]|~|Additional poster text: Kondome schützen vor HIV. Bei Syphilis bieten sie allerdings keinen 100%igen Schutz. Frage bei Haut- und Schleimhautveränderungen einen Arzt deines Vertrauens und lass dichregelmäßig untersuchen, denn eine Syphilis wird oft nicht bemerkt. Zudem erhöht eine unbehandelte infektion das HIV-Übertragungsrisiko. [Condoms protect against HIV. With Syphilis they do not offer 100% protection. Ask questions about skin and mucous membranes to a physician whom you are comfortable with, and go for a regular checkup as Syphilis is often unnoticed. Besides, an untreated infection increases the HIV transmission risk.

Title: Wir treffen die Entscheidung. Weiblich & positiv

BACK: Information about HIV-transmission, pregnancy, and personal choices.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW083.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Wir sind frauen. Wir sind HIV-positiv. Wir konnen schawanger werden. Jede von uns bestimmt selbst, ob sie ein Kind bekommt.
Alternate Title.descriptive: We make the decision. Pregnant & positive

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS: Verhütungsmöglichkeiten der HIV-Infektion
Description.note: Drawings next to each instructional caption show (in order): a man and a woman with their arms around one another; two men having anal sex, two men having oral sex, and a condom; two men exchanging hypodermic needle syringes.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW085.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS: Ways to protect against HIV infection
Description.inscription: AIDS ist eine schwere, heute noch nich heilbare Erkrankung. Vor den Infektion kann man sich aber leicht schützen. [AIDS is a serious condition with as yet no known cure. You can, however, protect yourself easily from infection.]|~|Verzicht auf walhlose Sexualkontakte; Bei Ungewissheit Kondome benutzen; Kein Austausch von Injektionsnadeln. [Avoid indiscriminate sexual contact; When in doubt use a condom; No exchange of hypodermic needles.]

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Stand together, walk together
Description.note: Red poster with alternating black and white titling. At bottom of poster are logos for the following events or sponsors: Christopher Street Day, Berlin 1993; IXth International Conference on AIDS, Berlin, June 7-11, 1993; Schwules Überfalltelefon [Gay Emergency Hotline] 030 216 22 26; Der Ansprechpartner der Berliner Polizei für gleichgeschlechtliche Lebenswesen -- Polizei Notruf [Berlin Police Dept. contact point for same-sex lifestyle -- police emergency] 110.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW086.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences

Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW087.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Welt-AIDS-Tag 1. Dezember
Description.note: Photograph of a red ribbon badge, which is the symbol of solidary and support for all people suffering with AIDS and HIV. World AIDS Day began in 1988, and has been held every year since, always on December 1.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW092.
Alternate Title.translated: World AIDS Day, 1 December
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Gemeinsame Rechte -- Gemeinsame Verantwortung [Mutual rights -- Mutual responsibility] (theme of World AIDS Day in 1995)|~|Additional poster text: Die Rote Schleife steht für Solidarität mit Menschen, die von AIDS betroffen sind. Zeigen Sie Anteilnahme und Engagement; Unterstützen Sie mit einter Spende die AIDS-Stiftungen und die Deutsche AIDS-Hilfe (Konto 4004 Stichwort: Welt-AIDS-Tag, bei allen Geldinstituten) oder andere Initiativen, die sich für Menschen mit HIV und AIDS einsetzen. [The red ribbon stands for solidarity with those afflicted with AIDS. Show your participation and commitment: lend your support by donating to AIDS charities and the Deutsche AIDS-Hilfe. (Account 4004, Keyword: Welt-AIDS-Tag, at any banking institution) or to any other initiatives on behalf of those afflicted with AIDS and HIV.]

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Urlaub von der Treue is das Ende der Sicherheit
Description.note: Photograph depicting a man with his arm around one woman, turning to look suggestively at another woman. They are both holding cocktails and she appears to be inviting his attention.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW105.
Alternate Title.translated: A vacation from fidelity is the end of security
Description.inscription: Die Bundeszentrale für gesundheitliche Aufklärung informiert ... [The Center for Health Information advises ...]|~|AIDS bekommt man nicht wie einen Schnupfen. Anstecken kann man sich bei ungeschütztem Sex mit unbekannten Partnern. Deshalb gilt im Urlaub, wie überall: Partnerschaftliche Treue ist der Beste Schutz vor AIDS. Wenn Sie noch Fragen haben, rufen Sie an: 0221/892031 [You don't get AIDS like you do a cold. You can be infected by having unprotected sex with strangers. So when on vacation, as always: Fidelity is the best protection against AIDS. For more information, call: 0221/892031]

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nicht jede Verbindung ist eine feste
Description.note: Depicts a young woman on the telephone, one hand caressing the phone cord. She is wearing a cocktail dress and has a string of pearls around her neck. The poster text "eine Feste Verbindung" is being used in reference to a clear telephone connection, which relates directly to the poster's graphic. The phrase can also be interpreted as "a permanent connection," as in a permanent relationship with another person. The poster is then suggesting that not all relationships are free of "static" or are permanent, indicating that no one should be taking chances with a sexual partner. Protection should always be used.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Additional poster text: Dem Leben zuliebe.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW126.
Alternate Title.translated: Not every connection is a clear one

Alternate Title.translated: From man to man

Title: Love island

They are seated near a palm tree, which boasts colorful condoms for fronds.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW134.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Mann/Mann
Description.note: This "Steck" cartoon depicts two naked men with their arms around each other, seated on a hilltop, smiling. Snow is falling around them. However, they are sitting under the "protection" of a condom, which is keeping them safe from the snowfall, and safe from the darkness, as light is eminating down from the condom above them. Since the snowflakes are suggestive of sperm, the two men can be thought of as being kept safe from the transmission of AIDS through the use of a condom.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW135.
Alternate Title.translated: Man man

Title: Mann/Frau
Description.note: This "Steck" cartoon depicts a naked woman and a naked man, with their arms around each other, seated on a hilltop, gazing upward with a started look on their faces. Snow is falling around them, but they are sitting under the "protection" of a condom, which is keeping them safe from the snowfall, and safe from the darkness, as light is eminating down from the condom above. Since the snowflakes can be suggestive of sperm, the couple can be thought of as being kept safe from the transmission of AIDS through the use of a condom.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW136.
