Name.creator: Projekt - PR
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS: Das kommt in den besten Familien vor
Description.note: Poster is a brochure depicting toys and an article explaining that AIDS does not discriminate between classes and ages. Article brings up AIDS awareness and the social stigma of somone who is infected.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW137.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS: it happens in the best of families

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Aids und Familie
Description.note: Poster has a short story for the words,Worries,  Hope, Memories, Support, Gossip. For worries, Ina is an infected single mother who worries about the care of her daughter when she dies. For hope, Margot and Peter have taken on four-year old Tobias whose parents died of AIDS, they hope there will be a cure soon. For memories, Marianne lost both her sons to AIDS, she is having a difficult time adjusting, even though they died some time ago. For support, Jorge was accompanied by his friend Marcus when Jorge found out he had AIDS; Marcus is supportive, non-judgmental and not HIV-infected. For gossip, Kai lives in a small town, the last time his brother, Manfred, visited his family, they were shocked at his sickly appearance. His parents worry about what the neighbors are thinking. Poster sums up their stories, bringing up issues and questions. AIDS is a big challenge to those infected and their friends and families. They're dealing with the situation. How to cope with the terminally ill. A loved one will die, they wonder why it happened to them and how they can help.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW137b.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS and the family

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS ist auch Männersache
Description.note: The poster is part of a published brochure entitled "AIDS ist auch Männersache." Divided by color into quadrants, the poster features four pictures: condoms (on an orange background), a man's hand holding a small barbell (on a blue background), an open lipstick container (on a pink background), and four Teddy bears (on a green background). In the lower right corner, a small AIDS ribbon appears next to the logo for the German anti-AIDS campaign slogan.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW138.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS is also an issue for men
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Geshundeit. Sexualität. Familie. Prävention. Kondome. Weltaidstag 1. Dezember [Health. Sexuality. Family. Prevention. Condoms. World AIDS Day, December 1].

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Warum verlangt Leda das von mir?
Description.note: Poster is a comical cartoon drawing of a swan, with a condom on its beak, lamenting "Why does Leda expect me to do this?" The obvious reference is to the classical Greek myth, "Leda and the Swan," in which Zeus transforms himself into a Swan in order to lay with Leda (and impregnate her). The condom symbolizes protection against pregnancy, and could also be considered a symbol of protection against AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaigns in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW139.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Why does Leda expect me to do this?

He is looking over at a jar of unrolled condoms of all shapes and sizes. There is a sign offering them for sale at half price. The pharmacist is standing behind the counter, also looking at the jar.

The places are numbered "2," "1" and "3" from left to right, with the "1" being raised above the other two numbers. The poster is encouraging people to choose the gold medal winner, to be number one, and choose protection when having sex.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaigns in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance]; and Mach's mit [Join in].|~|Poster held by Louise M. The phrase "Mach's mit" means to "take part" or to join those who are fighting AIDS infection by using a condom.|~|Part of two public AIDS campaigns in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance]; and Mach's mit [Join in].|~|Poster held by Louise M. Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ohne viel Worte : Alles was geil und sicher ist : Safer Sex
Description.note: The poster is a black and white photo of three men, standing in the shadows on a what appears to be a bridge. Two men are positioned together, one is seated on the railing of the bridge. He is wearing a "wife-beater" T-shirt, jeans, and boots. The second man is standing near him, his arm out streached, and hand holding the bridge support above. This man is wearing a leather vest with no shirt, leather pants, boots, and a leather cap adorned with a chain. The third man stands in the shadows, gazing to the same side as the couple, but not looking directly at them. The poster text infers that safe sex is "cool."|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW144.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Description.note: Depicts the heads and torsos of two young men, one leaning back to look into the eyes of the other positioned slightly behind him. Both are smiling. Each word of the poster text is placed on top of a pastel-colored oval, arranged in angled rows over the bottom third of the poster. The words suggest places and activities which appeal to both young men and women. Title: Mein Freund ist positiv. Ich liebe Ihn.

The man in the back, considerably older than the man in the front, has one arm wrapped around the younger man's chest. His other arm is reaching up, his hand clasping the younger man's head. The man in the foreground is posed with one hand grabbing his own belt buckle, his other hand disappearing between his and his lover's body. Both are somberly gazing at the camera.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW148.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Lust. Natur. Sicher
Description.note: Poster depicts two young men standing in front of a fountain-like structure. They are gazing intently at each other, while the man on the left is in the process of pulling at the unbuckled pants of the other young man, whose underwear is exposed. The background is classic, beautiful and romanesque, but is slightly out of focus. The camera is clearly accentuating the actions of the young men, and is suggestive of the sexual activity that is about to take place. The poster text suggests that feelings of lust are natural and beautiful, and that the use of protection should be considered to be a natural part of sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW149.
Alternate Title.translated: Lust. Nature. Safe

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Hart oder zart. Das ist nicht die Frage
Description.note: Poster depicts a scene from a park in which two male couples are involved in sexual encounters. In the foreground, a man naked from the waist up is handcuffed to a railing. Another man is standing behind him, leaning down, and pinching his nipples. In the background, leaning on the wall of a building, is another couple making out. Next to the couple in the foreground is another handcuffed wrist, but the image is cut off by the edge of the poster. The text of the poster suggests that how one prefers to have sex is not the problem. AIDS is transmitted by not using appropriate protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW150.
Alternate Title.translated: Rough or gentle. That's not the question

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Salomé's 1988 painting Reflexion/Reaktion II
Description.note: Poster reproduces the painting Reflexion/Reaktion II created by Salomé 1988 after his friend died from AIDS. The painting shows four bald men in different colored shirts and blue pants standing around a fifth man, who is naked and seated. One of the standing men is counseling the seated man, the others are thinking and reacting.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW173.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional text: Verzweiflung und Schweigen helfen nicht. Wir wollen kein Mitleid, sondern Unterstützung und Hilfe, wenn wir sie brauchen. Solidarität ist gefragt, nicht nur in Krisensituationen.|~|Translation: Despair and silence don't help. We don't want to be heartless, but support and help when you need it. Solidarity is required, not only in crisis situations.

Alternate Title.translated: Safer use - good for you and others - not only against HIV and Hepatitis.
Description.inscription: Teilen ist immer ein Risiko.  Für jeden Druck die eigene sterile Spritze und Nadel.

Title: Es gibt Dinge... die darf man nicht vergessen [inscribed].
Description.note: Part of the Gib AIDS keine Chance campaign.  Image of a Dalmatian chained to a lightpost in the middle of a desert and sand dunes with the sand tinted red.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW177.|~|Poster number GW246 has the same image but different text.
Alternate Title.translated: There are things one should never forget.
Description.inscription: Auch heute ist Aids ein grosses Problem.  Es bleibt eine tödlich Krankheit, für die es keine Schutzimpfung oder Heilung gibt.  Medikamente können den Ausbruch von Aids nach einer HIV-Ansteckung allerdings verzögern.

The second says Safe Sex and has a purple condom encased in a portion hanging from the pin.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW178.
Alternate Title.translated: Men, take on responsibility.

Name.creator: Deutsche AIDS-Hilfe e.V.
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Mut braucht unter stützung.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW183.
Description.inscription: HIV positiv.  Es kann sein, dass dir manchmal alles über den Kopf wächst.  Dann kostet es viel Kraft, nicht aufzugeben.  Anderen Frauen geht es genauso.  Miteinander reden, gemeinsam etwas unternehmen macht Mut.  Und Spass!  Es gibt viele Angebote für positive Frauen: Selbsthilfegruppen, Freizeitaktivitäten, Gesprächstreffs.  Die Mitarbeiterinnen der AIDS-Hilfen können Dir sagen, wo du sie findest.

Title: Er is Kollege, Nachbar, Vereinsmitglied, Liebhaber. Er ist schwul. Er hat weniger Rechte

The man is depicted in everyday settings, emphasizing the fact that being gay doesn't make a person different. Still, gays are not afforded the same rights as straight people in society.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW186.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sex Spass überraschung...?
Description.note: Poster depicts the legs of several men, some standing in front of and some behind a wrought iron fence. The men are wearing shorts, leather pants or jeans and leather chaps. The suggestion is that they are having anonymous sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW187.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional text: Geschlechtskrankheiten sind in kommen. Benutze Kondome. Sie verringern das Ansteckungsrisiko-schützen aber nicht völlig. Achte auf deinen Körper. Bei Veränderungen frage einen Arzt Deines Vertrauens. Lass dich regelmässig untersuchen. Viele Geschlechtskrankheiten machen sich kaum oder erst spät bemerkbar.|~|Translation: There are a lot of sexually transmitted diseases around. Use a condom. They reduce the risk of infection but not completely. Pay attention to your body. If you notice changes ask a doctor you trust. Get regular check-ups. Many diseases are only noticeable too late.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Familien-Bande
Description.note: Pastoral scene with seven people of varied gender, ethnicity, age, physical ability and possibly socio-economic status and sexual orientation. They are sitting or lying on and around a blanket on which there is a picnic basket and drinks spread out. Suggests that people can be brought together because of HIV and this is more important than their differences.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW188.
Alternate Title.translated: Family group
Description.inscription: Additional text: Uns trennt so vieles. Oder?|~|Translation: So much separates us. Or?

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Listen, learn, live
Description.note: Depicts young people of various ethnicities. Part of a campaign in Germany encouraging understanding and acceptance of foreigners. Suggestion is that foreigners do not bring HIV or AIDS into Germany.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW189.
Alternate Title.translated: Listen to each other, learn from each other, live with another
Alternate Title.inscribed: Einander zuhören, voneinander lernen, miteinander leben

Subject.conceptTopic: Gay men|~|Safe Sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Besser allein.
Description.note: Five men are depicted, each explaining why life is better alone.  The poster text cautions that no one wants to be truly alone and one must practice safe sex to keep himself and his partners healthy.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW190.
Alternate Title.translated: Better alone.
Description.inscription: Niemand ist gern einsam.  Zum zusammensein gehören Unabhängigkeit, Freiheit, Klarheit über eigene Ansprüche und Wünsche.Drum nimm dein Leben in die eigenen Hände.  Du bist verantwortlich - nicht nur beim Sex.  Sei du selbst, ohne faule Kompromisse.Für dich und deine Partner.  Für den Spass, die Liebe und das Leben mit anderen.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Force for change
Description.note: Multicolored depiction divided into a 3x3 arrangement of nine panels. The first eight panels each contain a person which is a composite of two halves of different faces. The people depicted are from different races, ethnicities, and age groups. The last panel shows a picture of the AIDS ribbon and a vertically aligned rainbow.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW191.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Wir können was verändern. Wir gehören zusammen.|~|Translated poster text: We can change something. We belong together.

Alternate Title.translated: Gay diversity, gay solidarity

Name.creator: Lauterbach, Martina
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Safer Use, Sauberes Spritzbesteck und Zubehör : Safer Sex, Kondome beim Sex
Description.note: Colored abstract illustration of two men and two women in an indoor warehouse-like location. Male in foreground (bottom left portion of poster) is preparing to inject drugs intravenously.  Women in foreground (center of poster) has a cigarette in her mouth and left arm crossed in front (so that hand is reaching ear?), seated near a used hypodermic needle. Male in background (bottom right of poster) standing shirtless, band tied around wrist, about to inject (or just finished injecting?) intravenous drugs. Women in background (upper right portion of poster) standing but slouched over indiscriminate orange object (as if typing or playing a keyboard?)|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW193.
Alternate Title.translated: Safe use with clean hypodermic equipment : Safe sex with condoms
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Safer Use und Safer Sex schützen vor HIV/AIDS und senken das Risiko einer Ansteckung mit Hepatitis und anderen Krankheiten!|~|Translation of poster text: Safer sex and safer use of syringe needles protects against AIDS and lowers the risk of hepatitis and other infectious diseases.

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW196.

Subject.conceptTopic: Assistance|~|AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Services for|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|HIV-positive persons--Counseling of|~|Community health services|~|AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Counseling of|~|HIV-positive persons--Services for
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Bedürfnisse haben Recht. [inscribed]
Description.note: Color depiction divided into three panels--one on top and two below.  Each panel consists of a photograph of a woman.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW197.
Alternate Title.translated: Needs have rights
Description.inscription: Text: Hiv positiv. Lebensqualität für dich vielleicht ein Fremdwort? Aber es gibt eine Reihe von staatlichen Zuschüssen und Vergünstigungen. Verzichte nicht aus Scham oder Angst auf das, was dir zusteht. Es sind keine Almosen -- du hast ein Recht darauf! Beratung, Information und tatkräftige Unterstützung bekommst du bei den Mitarbeiterinnen der AIDS-Hilfen. [HIV positive. Is quality of life a foreign word to you? But there is a set of state subsidies and privileges. Don't do without things you're entitled to because of shame or fear. This isn't charity -- you have a right to it! You can get consultation, information and strong support from AIDS-Hilfe employees.]

Name.creator: Mudra, Wolfgang
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Heimat Szene? [inscribed]
Description.note: Photograph of party-scene with men standing. Most of the men are clothed in black T-shirts and black pants while the rest are nude. The clothed men are interacting with each other. No one is interacting with the nude men, and many of them are staring at something off in the distance.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW198.
Alternate Title.translated: Homeland scene
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Aufmerksamkeit statt Nicht(be)achtung. [Awareness instead of not paying attention.]

Name.creator: Pusch, Detlev
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Positiv leben [inscribed]
Description.note: Related poster titles: "Bewusst leben" and "Schwul leben."|~|Black and white photographical depiction of two males in a bar. One whispers into the ear of the other. Two glasses of wine are on the bar counter.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW199.
Alternate Title.translated: Live positively
Description.inscription: Text: Jeder kann positiv sein. Ohne es zu wissen. Das Heisst für jeden, sich und andere zu schützen. Eben positiv leben. [Anyone could be positive. Without knowing it. That means everyone should protect himself and others. Just live positively.]

Name.creator: Jahreiss, M.|~|Pusch, Detlev|~|Warzecha, R.
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nein zum anfixen [inscribed]
Description.note: Photographic depiction of a young male and a young female conversing.  They are standing in a back alley.  He is leaning against a bicycle, while she is leaning against a fence.  A third male is walking by in background. There is graffiti written on a wall in the background which says: HEROIN RAUS! [Out with heroin!]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW200.
Alternate Title.translated: No to shooting up
Description.inscription: Text: Schon das erste Experiment mit einem gebrauchten Spritzbesteck kann zur HIV-Infektion führen. [Even the first experiment with a used hypodermic can lead to HIV infection.]

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex
Name.creator: Jahreiss, M.|~|Pusch, Detlev|~|Warzecha, R.
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Mann hat's. [inscribed]
Description.note: Blurred photographic depiction of a young female and two young males in a club-like scene. The female is seated a table which has two alcoholic drinks on it. One of the males is leaning towards the female, holding his arm around her. The other male is seated at the table facing the first male and the female. Both males are holding condoms and showing them to each other. Part of the seated male's reflection can be seen in a nearby mirror. Several other people are standing in the background.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW201.
Alternate Title.translated: He's got it.
Description.inscription: Text: Das Kondom in der Tasche und den Mut darüber zu reden. So kommt man sich näher. [A condom in his pocket and the courage to talk about it. This is how we get closer.]

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Sexually Transmitted Diseases--prevention & control|~|Sexually transmitted diseases--Prevention|~|HIV infections--Prevention
Name.creator: Heuler, Norbert|~|Pusch, Detlev
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nicht um jeden Preis--aber sicher [inscribed]
Description.note: Young male with open shirt, holding a glass of beer and leaning against a bar counter. Looking at (or speaking with?) another male. Text implies he may be a sex worker.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW202.
Alternate Title.translated: Not at any price--of course.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Beim Bumsen und Blasen schützt ein Gummi vor sexuell übertragbaren Krankheiten. [With fucking and blow jobs a condom protects against sexually-transmitted diseases.]

Name.creator: Mudra, Wolfgang
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Man as son, patient, employee, and customer [descriptive]
Description.note: Four panel depiction of a young male in various roles. Upper left panel depicts him assisting his mother with her blouse. Upper right panel depicts him on an examination table during his visit to the doctor. Lower left panel depicts him seated at a desk helping a client fill out an application. Lower right panel depicts him speaking with a woman (a store employee?) about a product he is holding.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW203.
Description.inscription: Poster text: Er ist Sohn, Patient, Angestellter, Kunde. Er ist schwul.  Er hat weniger Rechte. [He is son, patient, employee, customer. He is gay. He has fewer rights.]

Name.creator: Mudra, Wolfgang
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Family takes care [inscribed]
Description.note: Seven people of diverse backgrounds gathered together, smiling for a group photo. The scene is in a field where they are at a picnic. The photograph is shot in black and white. The majority of the picture is in grey scale, but a strip 1/3 of the poster's width is sepia-toned.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW204.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Okay: Ich bin schwul. Ich bin stark [inscribed]
Description.note: Sepia-toned photograph of a young gay male front and center, with two other males in the background.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW205.
Alternate Title.translated: Okay: I am gay. I am strong.

Title: Zeit für Safer Sex [inscribed]
Description.note: Male nude lying with torso facing upward. He is partially buried in the sand, with all but his pelvic area and some of his legs exposed. (Image is suggestive of sundial about to strike noon?)|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW206.
Alternate Title.translated: Time for safe sex

Name.creator: Deutsche AIDS-Hilfe e.V.
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Bewusst Sein: I Care…Do You? [inscribed]
Description.note: This poster shows the shirtless torso of a man with tattoos and piercings. His thumbs are hooked into the waistband of his pants, and he is looking directly at the viewer.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW207.
Alternate Title.translated: Be conscious

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Amit az AIDS-ről és megelőzéséről tudni kell
Description.note: Poster provides extensive textual information about AIDS & HIV transmission and prevention, including the role of drug and alcohol abuse in promoting risky behavior. A cartoon bird is depicted bringing information to the reader, and a cartoon monster represents the virus itself. Text also provides information about hotlines and other services, some anonymous, that provide information, testing and counseling services.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item HU001.
Format.dimensions: 43 cm. x 61 cm. (17 in. x 24 in.)
Alternate Title.translated: What one needs to know about AIDS and how to prevent it

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: De ha máshova mész el-- akkor védekezz!
Description.note: Poster depicts a blue movie ticket on a red background, and suggests that if a couple's date goes beyond just seeing a movie and includes sexual activity, protective measures should be taken.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item HU002.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: But if you go somewhere else, then you have to protect yourself

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ein fjölskylda gegn alnæmi. Umræða án fordóma [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster with red and black text on a white background, with a black and white image of a group of individuals, possibly a family, linking arms and partially circling a globe. The individuals who are facing forward are wearing red AIDS ribbons.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IC001.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: One family against AIDS. Discussion without prejudice

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Þad er Þess virdi! [inscribed]
Description.note: A multicolored cartoon without words depicts a man and a woman sitting on a bed. A voice "balloon" coming from the man has a picture of a condom in it. The next frames depict a hand holding a condom, and then a hand with colored nail polish putting a condom on an erect penis. The final frame shows the man and woman in bed with their eyes closed, possibly asleep, and covered by a sheet or blanket.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IC002.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: It's worth it!

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS is your responsibility. Protect your schools through education

The instructor is at the blackboard, pointing at the question "Responsible behaviour?" written in chalk.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item II001.|~|Date on back of poster, 1998, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Responsible behaviour?

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: All-India Institute of Medical Sciences. AIDS Education & Training Cell
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Skul mẹ milī muzhe eds kī jankarī kya tumhe bhī?
Description.note: Poster features a photograph of the torso of a young man looking pleasantly at the camera, with his jacket draped over one shoulder. He appears to be standing in the corridor of a school, as indicated by the poster's text.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item II002.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Central Council of Health & Family Welfare (India)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS : still no cure. Follow safe sex practices
Description.note: Poster depicts a doctor, arms crossed, frowning at a figure of a person who is being crushed by a large, black rectangular space which contains the poster text. The picture emphasizes the message: there is no cure for AIDS, so use protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item II003.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: All-India Institute of Medical Sciences. NGO AIDS Cell|~|East-West Committee (London, England)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Gaye piya pardesh kamane, eds na lekar aỵe. Paranarī se bache piya, to ghar mẹ eds kabhī na sataye. Asurakshit yaun sambanḍh eds phailta hai!
Description.note: Depicts three Hindi women, dressed in traditional clothing, sitting on a rug. They are talking to one another. It can be inferred that they are discussing the possibility of a husband contracting AIDS while overseas. The poster cautions to use protection when having sex with strangers.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item II004.
Alternate Title.translated: My beloved has gone overseas to earn a living. I hope he does not return with AIDS. Protect yourself from a strange woman, so that AIDS may never enter. AIDS spreads due to unprotected sex!

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: All-India Institute of Medical Sciences. NGO AIDS Cell
Name.creator: East-West Committee (London, England)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Yad Rakhẹ...Aap dhan kamane pardesh ja rahe hai, eds nahī!
Description.note: Poster depicts a painting of a young man, with a knapsack across his shoulder and a bag of belongings in his hand, walking away from a small house. The text reminds him to protect himself against AIDS while he is abroad working.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item II005.
Alternate Title.translated: Remember...You are going abroad to earn a living, not to have AIDS!

Title: Naya jīvan dījiye. Rakta-ek amulya uphar jo ap hi de sakte hẹ

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item II006.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Title: Test HIV : 10 buone norme per gli operatori sanitari che eseguono il test HIV [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: Test HIV : dieci buone norme per gli operatori sanitari che eseguono il test HIV
Description.note: The poster lists 10 suggestions for those who might be administering an HIV test or counseling about HIV testing. It reminds people to be sensitive, polite, careful, clear, patient, etc., when dealing with individuals who might be seeking or undergoing HIV testing. The poster has a blue border, and its right side is adorned with colorful question marks. An outline of a man is tumbling down the question marks, suggestive of a person who has many questions about HIV and might be feeling helpless.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT001.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Test HIV : 10 good norms for health officers to perform HIV testing

Title: Poster of an elderly couple representing compassion [descriptive]
Alternate Title.other: Mir AIDS?|~|AIDS betrëfft eis all. Gitt op Nummer sécher
Description.note: Part of "AIDS betrëfft eis all. Gitt op Nummer sécher."|~|Photograph of an elderly couple. Poster encourages individuals to have compassion for HIV-infected people, especially family members.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item LU001.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Text: Non, ce n'est pas notre cas. Mais nos enfants et nos petits enfants ne sont pas a l'abri. S'ils contractaient le SIDA, nous ne les laisserons pas tomber pour autant. Car, ils auraient encore plus besoin de notre soutien et de notre affection. Et vous, comment réagirrez-vous face a une atteinte du SIDA?
Alternate Title.descriptive: Elderly couple poster

Title: Poster of young people urging to have fun responsibly through safe sex [descriptive]
Alternate Title.other: Mir? AIDS?|~|AIDS betrëfft eis all. Gitt op Nummer sécher
Description.note: Part of "AIDS betrëfft eis all. Gitt op Nummer sécher."|~|Photograph of young people. Poster describes the pleasures of youth--partying, having fun, falling in love, and having sex. The poster stresses that concerns over AIDS need not keep young people from experiencing these pleasures, as long as they practice safe sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item LU004.
Description.inscription: Les discos, les concerts et les soirées folles, c'est ça la jeunesse. S'amuser, draguer et tomber amoureux. Des fois, ça même au lit dans les bras de notre conquête. Notre comportement n'a pas trop changé depuis qu'on parle du SIDA, sauf que nous utilisons maintenant des préservatifs.

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item LU005.

Gratis.|~|Additional text in German: Sein oder nicht sein...es gibt nur eine Antwort: AIDSTEST. Anonymn gratis.|~|Additional text in French: Etre ou ne pas être...il n'y a qu'une réponse: TEST DU DESPISTAGE DU SIDA. Anonyme, gratuit.|~|Additional text in English: To be or not to be...there is only one answer: AIDSTEST. Anonymous, free of charge.

Title: Beste Bart, we willen even zeggen dat je bij ons moet blijven werken [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a heartfelt message of sympathy to a student who is fighting for his life. The form of a letter tells the person that others care and they want to be in contact. To understand better, be willing to learn and listen to the notion of AIDS. "dat je bij ons" on the poster is blue while the rest of the letter is written in yellow. Perhaps the letter is written by more than one student.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE004.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Dear Bart, we just want to say that you must continue to fight for us
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Begrip En AIDS Horen Bij Elkaar.|~|Translated poster text: Listen to the concept of AIDS together.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Bé lekker ding [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster has a pink rolled up condom on a silver background. Condoms are lubricated with a protective coating and are available for a useful purpose. Protection is accessible, however, using them depends on one's choice. Hence to be safe or not to be safe, is the question.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE005.
Alternate Title.translated: It's a nice thing
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Ik vrij veilig of ik vrij niet.|~|Translated poster text: I rather be safe or I rather not.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Even aan denken [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a syringe with a red exclamation mark used for drugs. As a sign of danger, the exclamation mark emphasizes that the equipment is unsafe. Since drugs are usually hidden in large pockets of a coat, poster suggests not taking this risk.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE006.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Just think
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Altijd een schone op zak!|~|Translation of poster text: Always keep your pockets clean!|~|Aids-infolijn: 06-02 22 220. Project "Aids en Druggebruik" (AIDS Project on Drug Use).
Alternate Title.descriptive: Poster of a syringe with an exclamation mark running through it

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS [inscribed]

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Wil je er iets over weten? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster reveals different issues such as abortion, erection problems, infertility, pills, sexual abuse etc. Questions can be answered at various regions by dialing their respective numbers. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE008.
Alternate Title.translated: Do you want to know something about it?

Title: Poster of Bodyguard magazine cover with football player wearing protective gear [descriptive]
Description.note: Depicts sweaty bare chested male football player in locker room with dirty arms, wearing protective body gear. Shield logo in lower left shows condom and penis, crossed in insignia format.  Poster extends concept of wearing protective equipment for all contact sports to wearing protection for sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE012.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Bodyguard.  Als je lijf je lief is pak je exemplaar van Bodyguard, de glossy over homoseks, bij horeca, sauna of GGD of bestel bij de Schorerstichting.|~|Translation of poster text: If you love your body, get your issue of Bodyguard, the magazine about homosexuality, at ... the bathhouses of the Dept of Public Health or at the main offices of Schorerstichting.

Title: Wereldwijd 13 Miljoen AIDSwezen [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster publicizes the organizations that are willing to help give a future to those affected with AIDS. Three siblings in the poster are standing on a burial site looking down on the grave. Their sad expression for a great loss, is the result of this fast spreading disease.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE013.|~|Date on back of poster, 2001, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: 13 million people affected with AIDS worldwide
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Miriam heeft geen vader en geen moeder meer, alleen een broer en een zus. Miljoenen aidswezen moeten zichzelf zien te redden. Stop AIDS Now! werkt aan zorg, preventie en een vaccin.|~|Translated poster text: Miriam has no father or mother and only has a brother and sister. Millions of people must try to save themselves from AIDS. Stop AIDS Now! Work for the care, prevention, and vaccine for AIDS.
Alternate Title.descriptive: Poster of three siblings who have lost their parents, standing on a burial site

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS

Title: India 4.100.000 mensen met HIV/AIDS [inscribed]

Poster questions whether you are aware if you are infected or not. In other words, are you taking care of your body?|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE014.|~|Date on back of poster, 2001, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: 4,100,100 people infected with HIV/AIDS in India|~|8 people are diagnosed per hour

Name.creator: SOA AIDS Nederland
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Als je later kinderen wilt: gebruik dan nu een condoom! [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster shows a hand holding a ring box with a condom. Background is red to express the danger of Chlamydia for women. Poster encourages using a condom now to protect a woman's ability to have children in the future.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE015.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: If you want children later: then use a condom now!
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Leder jaar worden naar schatting 1.000 vrouwen ONVRUCHTBAAR door chlamydia.|~|Translated poster text: In a tragic year, a rough estimate of 1,000 women become infertile through Chlamydia.
Alternate Title.descriptive: Poster of a condom in a ringbox held in a hand

Name.creator: SOA AIDS Nederland
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Wil je geen soa als souvenir? Gebruik dan een condoom! [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster recommends using a condom to prevent long term consequences (souvenir, keepsake as in the poster) of sexually transmitted diseases. Background is green to show emotional connection with safety. Poster assures one's security with the usage of protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE016.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Do you want an STD as a souvenir? Use a condom then!
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Neem condooms mee op vakantie. Als je deze gebruikt, weet je zeker dat je veilig vrijt.|~|Translated poster text: Take condoms with you on a holiday. If you consistently use them, you can be sure of your safety when you go out.
Alternate Title.descriptive: Poster of a condom in a ringbox held in a hand

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Sexually transmitted diseases--Prevention|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Syphilis
Name.creator: SOA AIDS Nederland
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Met syfilis ben je vatbaarder voor hiv. Gebruik daarom een condoom! [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster informs the linkage between sexually transmitted infections and the HIV virus. HIV transmission is more likely for those infected with STIs. Therefore, the act of using a condom can prevent one and stop the risk for another.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE017.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: With Syphilis, you are more susceptible for HIV. So use a condom!
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Hiv dringt MAKKELIJKER het lichaam binnen als je een andere soa hebt.|~|Translated poster text: HIV penetrates the body MORE EASILY if you carry another STD.
Alternate Title.descriptive: Poster of a condom in a ringbox held in a hand

Subject.conceptTopic: Chlamydia|~|Chlamydia Infections--prevention & control|~|Sexually transmitted diseases|~|Chlamydia Infections--transmission|~|Safe Sex|~|Awareness

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Weet je zeker dat je vriendje geen chlamydia heeft? Gebruik toch maar een condoom! [inscribed]

Because one may have the disease and not know it, poster suggests using protection to avoid unexpected transmission.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE018.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Are you certain that your friend does not have Chlamydia? Nevertheless, use a condom!

Title: Poster of a condom with male and female symbols
Description.note: A drawing of a green condom in the lower left corner covers the arrow of a red male symbol, and is encircled by a blue combined male/female symbol. In the top right corner, a naked man and woman are joined hand to foot to form a circle. Text in English, Norwegian, French, Russian and German along the left border of the poster gives information about preventing HIV transmission, and gives the number of an AIDS hotline. The yellow background of the poster is a photograph of male genitalia.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Poster text juxtaposes the notion of sexual infidelity with the use of a condom to preserve life.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO003.

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Portugal. Commissão Nacional de Luta Contra a SIDA
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: VIH/SIDA: os factos [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster presents the facts about the transmission of HIV and AIDS. Divided into two parts, poster presents a sequence of images to separate the facts from the misperceptions. AIDS is transmitted through: unprotected sex, contact with contaminated blood, from mother-to-child during pregnancy and breast-feeding, and sharing of needles. AIDS is not transmitted through: food or silverware, mosquito bites, coughing and sneezing, shaking hands and hugging, use of public restrooms, safe sex (condom), and social contact.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO004.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: HIV/AIDS: the facts
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: A SIDA não tem cura... Não discrimine!|~|Translated poster text: There is no cure for AIDS ... Do not discriminate!

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Portugal. Commissão Nacional de Luta Contra a SIDA
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: SIDA espreita-o. Previna-se. Use preservativo [inscribed]

Poster suggests the precaution against the lurking and hidden danger of AIDS is a condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO005.
Alternate Title.inscribed: AIDS is watching you. Take precautions. Use a condom

Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Papua New Guinea|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS: we are all at risk
Alternate Title.other: Protect yourself from AIDS|~|AIDS is the most serious health threat our country faces. Every month 100 Papua New Guineans will catch the AIDS virus. Our sons, daughters, brothers, sisters, wantoks are all at risk.
Description.note: Top half of the poster is textual, with subheadings "How do you catch the AIDS virus?" "Why do we need to protect ourselves?" and "Let's talk about AIDS." Lower half of the poster depicts Dr. Clement Malau of the PNG National AIDS Council sitting at a desk. On the desk is a laptop computer with a map of Papua New Guinea on its screen, a microscope, and specimen tubes. The poster suggests the importance of open communication and scientific understanding of the causes and prevention of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PP001.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Subject.conceptTopic: HIV-positive persons|~|Social advocacy|~|Awareness|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: A mí me importa ... Y a ti? [inscribed]
Description.note: Additional poster text: Día mundial del SIDA. 1 de Diciembre de 2001. "Debemos implicar a los jóvenes que viven con el VIH/SIDA en la lucha contra la epidemia. Después de todo, ellos son quienes mejor saben lo que significa vivir con SIDA". Kofi Annan, Secretario General de las Naciones Unidas. "Párate un momento, escucha y aprende todo lo que puedas acerca del VIH/SIDA. La prevención y la vida... ¡están en tus manos!" Joey DiPaolo, educador sobre el SIDA que vive con VIH.|~|Picture of Joey DiPaolo with Kofi Annan holding an open book titled "Living Proof."|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP001.
Alternate Title.translated: I care... Do you?

Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|Condoms|~|AIDS (Disease)--Risk factors|~|Awareness|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Spain. Ministerio de Sanidad y Consumo
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Si Da. No Da. No cambies tu vida por el SIDA [inscribed]
Description.note: Additional poster text. Si Da: Intercambiarse la maquinilla de afeitar y otros objetos personales cortantes. Transmisión de la madre al feto. Tatuaje con agujas sin esterilizar. Hacer el amor con portadores (Hombre-mujer). Relaciones homosexuales con portadores. Utilizar la misma jeringuilla. Intercambiarse el cepillo de dientes. No Da: Practicar cualquier tipo de relaciones sexuales utilizando perservativo. Bañarse con portadores. (Duchas, piscinas, etc.). Las picaduras de insectos. Jugar con portadores. Beber del mismo vaso o la misma botella. Darse la mano. Besarse and abrazarse. Cambiarse la ropa. Utilizar los mismos servicios que los portadores.|~|Images of female and male gender symbols engaging in different activities. On one side of the poster, they are depicting and describing activities that can increase the risk of transmission of the HIV virus. Activities such as having unprotected sex with a person infected with the virus, sharing needles, toothbrushes or razors. One the other half, the symbols are depicting and describing activities through which transmission is not possible or the risk of transmission is decreased. Some of these activities include having protected sex, kissing, hugging and shaking hands.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP002.
Alternate Title.translated: Yes this transmits. No this doesn't transmit. Don't change your life because of AIDS

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences

Alternate Title.translated: Condoms are romantic

Alternate Title.translated: I care... Do you?
Description.inscription: A mí me importa... Y a ti? Día mundial del SIDA. 1 de Diciembre de 2001. "No se puede saber si alguien está infectado por el VIH tan solo con mirarlo. Protegete: ponte un preservativo." Ronaldo, Embajador de Buena Voluntad del PNUD y Representante Especial para la Campaña Mundial contra el SIDA. "No es fácil hablar del SIDA si nadie te escucha. A mí me gusta escuchar." Luca, voluntario de Arché, una ONG italiana que se ocupa del SIDA.|~|Image of Ronaldo and Luca holding a soccer ball on a soccer field.

Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Día mundial del SIDA. 1 de Diciembre de 2001. "Nuestra voz es importante. Cada uno de nosotros debe usar las aptitudes que tiene para fomentar la sensibilizacion sobre VIH/SIDA." Ricky Martin, cantante. "Escuchando a los niños jugando con ellos, viédolos sufrir, he aprendido a ser fuerte, dejando de lado la pena y el miedo." Silvia, voluntaria que trabaja con niños VIH-positivos. "Yo siempre pensaba como tú que el VIH no me afectaría nunca... hasta que di positivo." Clint Walters fundador de Health Initatives for Youth.

Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Transmission
Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Comité Ciudadano Anti-SIDA Madrid|~|Madrid (Spain : Region). Servicio Regional de Salud
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: SIDA: hoy X hoy, la única, vacuna: información y prevención [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP009.|~|Poster advocates arming oneself with knowledge about preventive measures as the most effect "vaccine" against AIDS. It depicts some of the misperceptions about AIDS transmission: you can't get it by kissing, holding hands, playing with an AIDS patient, using the same utensils as an AIDS patient, or using the same toilet. It also depicts ways to prevent contracting AIDS: don't use the same razor or toothbrush, use a condom, and use unused syringes.
Alternate Title.translated: Day X Day, the only, vaccination: information and prevention
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Asi no se contrae el SIDA [with depictions of how AIDS can't be contracted underneath]; Asi se previene el SIDA [with depictions of how to prevent it].

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Spain. Ministerio de Sanidad y Consumo
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Yo [corazón] tú; yo [condón] tú [inscribed]
Alternate Title.other: I love you; I protect you|~|Yo amo tú; yo protejo tú
Description.note: Part of the "SIDA--Campaña para la prevención"; campaign.|~|Translation of poster text: Every day more men and women get infected by AIDS. Unfortunately, AIDS exists. Fortunately, so do methods of avoiding it. Live life as normal. And if you have sex, use a condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP010.
Alternate Title.translated: I [heart] you; I [condom] you
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Cada día son más los casos de hombres y mujeres afectados por el SIDA. Desgraciadamente, el SIDA existe. Afortunadament, formas de evitarlo, también. Haz tu vida normal. Y si tienes relaciones sexuales, utiliza un preservativo.

Subject.conceptTopic: Mapplethorpe, Robert|~|Homosexuality, Male|~|Gay culture|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|Marginality, Social|~|Haring, Keith|~|Mercury, Freddie|~|AIDS (Disease)--Switzerland
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Escludere per l'AIDS? Escluso!
Description.note: Shows a nude man floating in front of a triptych of stars, a moon, and a cloud with an angel. Below him is an assortment of items associated with gay culture (a book of Robert Mapplethorpe's photography, a Freddie Mercury album, a Keith Haring painting) as well as holiday decor and wrapped presents. The poster may represent the gifts of gay culture to the mainstream and argue against thinking of the gay community as separate and the only part of society that has to deal with AIDS. It also suggests the decimation of the gay community by AIDS, as represented by the three artists, each of whom died of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ009.
Alternate Title.translated: To exclude because of AIDS? Excluded!

Title: Ohne? Ohne mich
Description.note: A color photograph shows a man dressed in a suit and tie seated behind a desk in an office, surrounded by shelves full of books. His closed right hand is raised with thumb pointing up in a "thumbs up" sign; on  his thumb is a condom. The word "ohne" (without) is next to the condom. The man is probably in his thirties, wears glasses, and has a professional desk job, perhaps as an archivist, lawyer or accountant. The message is that a mature, well-educated professional gay man will not have sex unless condoms are used for protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ018.
Alternate Title.translated: Without it? Without me
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Eine Präventionskampagne der Aids-Hilfe Schweiz in Zusammenarbeit mit dem Bundesamtes für Gesundheitswesen.|~|cR Basel

His left arm rests on the top of the door, while his right arm is toward the viewer; his right hand is closed in a "thumbs up" sign, with a condom on his thumb. He wears a black leather jacket and his sunglasses are shoved back on the top of his black curley hair.  The message is that a sporty young gay man will not have sex unless condoms are used.|~|A decal on the windshield shows "92" possibly a year of registration of the automobile.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Wir schützen uns, weil wir uns lieben
Description.note: Two muscular young men, clad only in undershorts and shorts, are enjoying a picnic in a grain field.  In the foreground, one man lies on his back on a blanket, shorts open in front and pulled down to reveal his undershorts. He holds hands and looks fondly into the face of his lover, who is sitting up next to him, dressed only in undershorts.  Their eyes display love for each other.  An open picnic basket sits nearby, and one can see some bread, some wine, some watermelon, and some red condoms. The scene is one of idyllic pleasure, and also of safety and security.|~|Part of "Stop AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ020.
Alternate Title.translated: We protect each other, because we love one another
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Eine Präventionskampagne des Bundesamtes für Gesundheitswesen, in Zusammenarbeit mit der Aids Hilfe Schweiz.|~|SEILER DDB NEEDHAM/cR

Title: Nous nous protégeons parce que nous nous aimons
Description.note: A color photograph shows a man and a woman playfully relaxing in a small boat, secluded by some reeds at the edge of a large lake. The man, dressed in undershorts, is leaning back on a bench in the boat, looking at the woman and teasing her by dangling her bra from one outstretched hand.  The woman is facing him, seated on another bench, and is splashing him with a little water from the lake. She is covered by some clothing draped from breast to hips. Next to the man is a straw bag draped with an article of clothing; on top are seen two red unopened condoms.  The scene is one of sexy playfulness, love, fun, safety and security because the man uses condoms for protection.|~|Part of "Stop AIDS" campaign|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ021.

Title: Man and woman embracing, woman kissing man
Description.note: A young man and a woman embrace as the woman gently kisses his cheek. Seen only from the shoulder up, they appear to be undressed. The woman holds a partially opened condom packet in one hand. The man has dark short hair, a moustache and a small beard. The woman has blond short hair and wears a small flower earring.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ025.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Eine Präventionskampagne des Bundesamtes für Gesundheitswesen, in Zusammenarbeit mit der Aids Hilfe Schweiz|~|SEILER DDB NEEDHAM/cR

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ich habe Aids. Ich habe Angst vor Ihrer Angst vor mir
Description.note: A black and white photo in which a young man stands alone against an empty background, on the right side of the photo. He wears jeans, a long sleeved shirt with open collar, and a vest open at the front.  With dark hair and a large dark moustache, he looks dolefully toward the viewer, left hand placed on his waist, right hand in his jeans pocket. The photo evokes a sombre mood of lonliness and fear, which encourages to viewer to think about being in the same state as the young man, and emphasizes the need to stop AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ026.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: I have AIDS. I'm afraid of the fear you have of me
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Die Solidaritätskampagne der Aids-Hilfe Schweiz, in Zusammenarbeit mit dem Bundesamt für Gesundheitswesen.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: En tant qu'homme malade du Sida ne suis-je plus qu'un malade du Sida?
Description.note: A black and white photograph in the center of which stands a man looking directly at the viewer, his left hand in his trousers pocket, with a thoughtful, inquiring, and vaguely challenging look on his face.  He is nicely  dressed in slacks and a long-sleeved sweater, just an ordinary man aged in his thirties, balding in front, with a goatee and moustache.  His challenge is to be seen as an individual human being, not just a sick man with AIDS.|~|Part of the "Stop AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ027.
Alternate Title.translated: In my capacity as a man sick with Aids, am I nothing more than just a sick man with AIDS?
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Campagne de prévention de l'Aide Suisse contre le SIDA, en collaboration avec l'Office fédéral de la santé publique.

Title: Präservative stoppen AIDS
Description.note: A closeup color photograph of two faces next to one another in which only one eye from each face is seen. The "o" in the title word "stoppen" is a pink condom. The message is that condoms prevent the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Title: Blocca l'AIDS. Non cominciare.
Description.note: A closeup color photograph of two faces very close together, where only one eye from each face is seen. The face on the left has fair skin and a blue eye, that on the right has dark skin and a dark eye. In between the faces is the tip of a syringe, held up by one of the people, with both eyes focused upon it. The message is that sharing needles can transmit AIDS; do not share needles.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ033.
Alternate Title.translated: Stop AIDS. Don't start.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Campagna di prevenzione dell'AIUTO AIDS SVIZZERO, in collaborazione con l'Ufficio federale della sanità pubblica.|~|cR Basel

Title: ...mit Gebrauchten nie!

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sie steht für ein neues Gefühl...
Description.note: A safety pin is shown pinned onto the lapel of a man's suit. The poster image is a black and white photo showing the left-hand side of a man's torso, from his chin to his shoulder; he is wearing a tie, a shirt with button-down collar, and a suit. Vertically along the right side of the poster are five olive-yellow boxes containing the texts, with a little safety pin image next to each one.  What the safety pin stands for are: new feelings, responsibility, solidarity, trust, and open verbal communication. If a man practices safe sex, his wearing of the safety pin would let others know that they can talk with him about it.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ037.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: It stands for new feelings...
Description.inscription: Partial poster text: Sie steht für ein neues Gefühl: lustvoller Sex, ohne Angst. Sie steht für Verantwortung ... Solidarität ... Vertrauen ... offene Gesprächsbereitschaft. Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Transmission
Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: How AIDS is spread
Description.note: Poster describes four ways by which AIDS is spread: sexual intercourse, contaminated medical instruments, pregnancy and blood transfusions. Illustrations depict a naked man and woman in silhouette, a man receiving medical treatment from a traditional healer, a kneeling pregnant woman, and a woman receiving a blood transfusion.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG001.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDS is spread mainly through sexual intercourse with an infected person. AIDS is spread through blood contaminated instruments. AIDS is spread through infected woman during pregnancy to her unborn child. AIDS is spread through infected blood transfusion. Prevent AIDS! Have sexual intercourse with a faithful partner for life. Accept medical treatment only from trained health workers in health centres where equipment is kept sterile and blood is checked against AIDS.|~|Poster is item 7 in Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What does a person with AIDS look like? AIDS can look like many other diseases. Don't be confused. Don't spread rumors
Description.note: Illustrations depict 6 other diseases or conditions that can easily be misidentified as AIDS. Poster suggests that people should not assume that someone has AIDS just because they appear sick, and the importance of testing for people who suspect they have AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG002.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDS or measles? AIDS or tuberculosis? AIDS or alcoholism? AIDS or malnutrition? AIDS or typhoid? AIDS or cancer? See a qualified medical person for tests if you think you or someone you know may have AIDS.|~|Item 5 in the Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What have you heard about AIDS? Don't guess the answers! Learn the truth about AIDS!
Description.note: Illustration depicts a young girl and boy walking. The girl is whispering in the boy's ear. Poster suggests that children should learn the facts about AIDS rather than spreading misinformation.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG003.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: What does it mean? What can we do for people who have it? How does it harm us? Can it be cured? Who can get it? What does it look like? What causes it? Which of us has it? How can we stop it?|~|Item 3 in the Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Care for people with AIDS : protect your patients from infections, protect yourself and others from AIDS
Description.note: Illustration depicts a man in a sick bed with a woman and child caring for him. Additional illustrations show 4 ways to prevent the transmission of AIDS: washing hands, covering wounds, keeping the patient clean and not sharing sharp instruments like razors.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG004.
Description.inscription: Item 10 in the Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: You can not get AIDS from...prevent AIDS. Learn the ways it can and cannot spread. AIDS is not spread in the ways shown above.
Description.note: Illustrations depict four ways AIDS is not spread: contact such as holding hands or kissing, sharing clothing and combs, sharing cups or utensils, or from insects or animals. Poster suggests that people should educate themselves about how AIDS is spread.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG005.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDS is spread through sexual intercourse with an infected person, through blood contaminated instruments, through infected women to their unborn children and through infected blood transfusions.|~|Item 8 of Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Previnase do SIDA
Description.note: Poster depicts a happy family together. A baby held by its mother is receiving a shot from a health care worker, a member of the "ministry of health," as indicated on label on medical bag. Health care worker is using sterile medical supplies.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG006.
Alternate Title.translated: Prevent AIDS
Description.inscription: Caption: Tenha relações sexuais somente com um parceiro que lhe seja fiel. Só aceite tratamento médico do pessoal de saúde qualificado.|~|Translation: Have sexual relations with a faithful sex partner. Get medical treatment only from trained health care workers.

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Can you spot which person carries HIV? The answer is no!
Description.note: Illustration depicts 9 people standing together, male and female, young and old. Text suggests that we shouldn't assume someone isn't infected just because they look healthy.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG007.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: The AIDS virus can hide in a person's blood for many years. People who carry AIDS may look and feel healthy, but they can still give AIDS to others!|~|Adapted from Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control (Item 5).
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex
Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Durex Information Service for Sexual Health
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Don't mess up, dress up! [inscribed]
Description.note: Purple background with yellow and light purple text. Cartoons of two personified penises. One penis has a worried expression; the other is covered by a condom and is smiling, winking, and making a thumbs-up sign. Lower right corner shows logo for Durex, a brand of condoms. Poster humorously promotes the use of condoms for safe sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK001.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Nowadays, when you have sex, you need to protect yourself. Condoms are the only sure way of reducing the risks of unplanned pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases… including HIV/AIDS. You can buy condoms from chemists, supermarkets, petrol stations and vending machines. There’s more to condoms than you think—check out the instructions next time you buy a pack.
