Subject.conceptTopic: Sexually Transmitted Diseases--therapy|~|Sexually transmitted diseases--Prevention|~|Sexually Transmitted Diseases--diagnosis
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What am I? [inscribed]
Description.note: Background stripes of pink, green, purple, and blue; text in white & black. Depicts four rows of curios. Row 1: drawing of Freud's profile with naked man as face; toothbrush with popsicle on stick; pineapple filled with ice; bear sculpture with banana as tail. Row 2: "Ken" doll; ceramic teapot shaped as cottage; photo of gnome and pink flamingo lawn decorations; greeting card with picture of cowboy. Row 3: hand grenade; pen with photo of nude man; pastille candies with red hearts. Row 4: Bandages of the invisible man; green & blue bugs; mer-man.|~|Sponsors: Community HIV and AIDS Prevention Strategy; Gay Men’s Project; Slap fM; Gay Men Fighting AIDS; Healthy Gay Manchester; Gay Men's Health Matters; BIGUP; Yorkshire MESMAC; Naz Project London; The Network.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK014.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: I’m free ‘n’ easy and fun to pick up. I’m easily passed on. I can be invisible and damage your health. I’m a sexually transmitted disease. Most STIs are easily treated, but if left can cause serious health problems. Regular check-ups are recommended to detect STIs which may go unnoticed.

Subject.conceptTopic: Social advocacy|~|HIV-positive persons--Counseling of|~|HIV infections|~|George House Trust|~|AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Counseling of
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Our response to HIV [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster in two halves: top half has blue background; bottom half, red. Text in white. Promotes the services offered by the George House Trust. George House Trust, established in 1985 (as "Manchester AIDSline"), is one of the oldest HIV charities in the UK.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK015.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional text: Advice, befriending, campaigning, challenging discrimination, emotional support, information, peer support, representation, therapies, training.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: When Martin was told he had AIDS, his family couldn't believe it. After all, he is 64 [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of three smiling people sitting on a blanket in the grass: a middle-aged man and woman, and a young man. Poster suggests that anyone can be infected with AIDS, not just young gay men, and describes London Lighthouse as a resource for older people who are HIV-positive.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK016.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Not surprisingly they came to us. Still numb. Still protesting that they thought AIDS was only a 'young person's' illness. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. We're now helping them accept Martin's illness and carry on with their lives. Old or young. Him or her. White or black. Straight or gay. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Services for|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|Social networks|~|AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Family relationships|~|Counseling
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Their son was diagnosed HIV+. Their son went to them for support. Their son was told he wasn't their son anymore. [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a smiling middle-aged couple holding a "Happy Anniversary" cake with lit candles. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for HIV-positive people even when their families reject them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK017.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Then, their son came to us. He told us his story. We listened. We explained that his parents weren't evil. Just ignorant. Overwhelmed by fear. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. In fact, his parents are now talking to us. Which is a start. Straight or gay. Old or young. White or black. Him or her. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: She told her husband she was HIV+. He took it badly. She told her best friends. They took off [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a woman's face reflected in a mirror. She has a black eye. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for HIV-positive women whose families and friends reject them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK018.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: She told us. We listened. And listened. She told us she'd spent her life caring for others and that now, when she really needed hope, there was no-one. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. By the way, she left her husband and is now rebuilding her life again. Her or him. Young or old. Gay or straight. Black or white. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Amy's dad couldn't bring himself to accept he had AIDS. Now he can. He just can't bring himself to tell her. [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a man holding a young girl. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for HIV-positive men with families.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK019.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Could you? Probably not. That's why he came to us. We didn't tell Amy for him though. We just helped him find the strength to tell her himself. That's how we work. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. Amy doesn't understand yet, but one day, she will. Young or old. Him or her. Black or white. Straight or gay. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Derek lost his entire family to AIDS. One year later, they're still not talking to him. [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a bald man with his back to the viewer, talking on a telephone. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for people with AIDS when their families reject them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK020.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: That's why he called us. We always listen. We never judge. We know that family rejection can sometimes be more distressing than the illness. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. We're still trying to help Derek's family understand. Black or white. Him or her. Young or old. Straight or gay, AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Bhangra against homophobia [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of 2 Indian women embracing. Poster suggests the importance of speaking up against homophobia and discrimination based on sexuality, and provides contact information for 3 organizations that can provide information about sexuality and safer sex: Kiss (a Naz Project London), the Metro Centre (a centre for lesbian, gay and bisexual people), and Shakti (South Asian Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transexual Network).|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK021.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 1 in 4 Lesbian, Gay and Bisexual people experience homophobic violence and harassment. Discrimination on the grounds of sexuality is a violation of human rights. Silence reinforces homophobic attitudes. Don't be part of the problem.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences

Poster also has logo for Rubberstuffers, an organization that provides free condoms in bars and clubs.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK022.

Subject.conceptTopic: Intravenous drug abuse|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|Sexual abstinence
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: There's a simple way to prevent AIDS. [inscribed]
Description.note: Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign. Picture of a woman sitting on a chair with her legs crossed. The concept of the poster is to promote abstinence from sex and drug use as an effective way to avoid the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US003.
Description.inscription: There's a simple way to prevent AIDS. You want to be risk-free from AIDS? Don't have sex.  And as long as you aren't shooting drugs, you'll be fine. No worries about who's slept around, who's had blood tests, and whether your condoms are latex or not.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What have you got against a condom? [inscribed]
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS". The poster is a picture of a woman.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US004.
Description.inscription: What have you got against a condom? The simple act of putting on a condom can save your life, if they're used properly and every time you have sex. For more information about AIDS and condoms, call 1-800-342-AIDS.

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Why alcohol, crack and other drugs can put you at risk for the AIDS virus. [inscribed]
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|The poster is a blurry image of two people.  It implies that drug and alcohol use can impaire the mind, leading to behavior that puts one at risk of HIV infection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US005.
Description.inscription: Why alcohol, crack and other drugs can put you at risk for the AIDS virus. They cloud your thinking. You already know that shooting up drugs and sharing needles put you at risk for AIDS. But actually, other drugs such as crack, alcohol and marijuana can put you at risk because they cloud your thinking. And when your thinking is clouded, you take foolish chances. When you're high, you may have sex. That's risky stuff. So think clearly. Don't risk AIDS. If you'd like more information on the relationship between AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases, call the National AIDS hotline. 1-800-342-AIDS. The hotline for the hearing impaired is 1-800-AIDS-TTY.

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: United States. Public Health Service|~|Whitman-Walker Clinic

Title: Men of the 90's [inscribed]
Description.note: Image of two men, one is embracing the other and holding a condom in one hand.  The poster implies that whether either man is HIV positive or negative, they are doing the safe thing by protecting themselves with a condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US006.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Men of the 90's. Positive. Negative. Both do the safe thing. AIDS program fo Whitman-Walker Clinic, Inc.

Title: You can't get AIDS- by shaking hands, or by hugging, in restaurants, or in restrooms. [inscribed]
Description.note: Black, white and red poster with pixtures of two people shaking hands, hugging, a served plate and a mens and womens restroom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US007.
Description.inscription: See beyond fear. You can't get AIDS- by shaking hands, or by hugging, in restaurants, or in restrooms. AIDS doesn't spread through casual contact. Don't let fear get in the way of facts. Take the time to learn about AIDS.

Subject.conceptTopic: Sexually Transmitted Diseases--prevention & control|~|Unsafe sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Why there's a connection between sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign. The poster depicts a young man leaning into his open school locker. He is holding two books in his hands.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US008.
Description.inscription: Poster text: Why there's a connection between sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS. Simple. The same type of sexual behavior that can infect you with gonorrhea, gential herpes, syphilis, and other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) can also infect you with something else... the AIDS virus. You get STDs by having sex with someone who is infected. That's bad enough. But if you continue the same unprotected sexual behavior, you could get something you can't cure. AIDS. If you'd like more information on the relationship between AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases, call the National AIDS hotline. 1-800-342-AIDS. The hotline for the hearing impaired is 1-800-AIDS-TTY.

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US012.
Alternate Title.translated: Dangerous tracks
Description.inscription: Ana está saliendo con un chico que se inyecta drogas. Ella está cometiendo un error grave. El puede adquirir el SIDA por compartir las agujas de las jeringas. Ana podría adquirir el SIDA por culpa de él. Ella tiene varias opciones: Hacer que él deje de inyectase drogas o buscarle ayuda profesional y tratamiento contra las drogas; u olvidarse de él, o por lo menos asegurarse que cuando tienen relaciones sexuales, él use un condón.

Name.creator: McElhaney, Jeff
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Stops transmission-fluid leaks
Alternate Title.other: Use condoms. There's living proof they stop AIDS
Description.note: Poster depicts a black and white photograph of a used, stretched out condom. The image of the condom connects to the title to suggest the importance of a condom as prevention to the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US018.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Recently, top researchers filled condoms with AIDS virus-infected fluid and subjected them to pressure tests for three weeks.  No virus leaked through.  The fact of life here: Wearing condoms stops AIDS from spreading.  So try out this newfound bit of carnal knowledge: Using a condom can save your life.
Alternate Title.descriptive: [Condom] stops transmission-fluid leaks

They smile happily, giving the sense of a closeknit and loving family. The intention is to make men think hard about the risks of going out with their friends and having sex with women of the streets. They could bring AIDS back to their family.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US019.
Alternate Title.translated: Three reasons not to go out on the street with the guys
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Yo creía que tenía que salir con otras mujeres para pasar un buen rato. Hasta que me di cuenta que estaba arriesgando a mi familia. Es que, el SIDA está allí...|~|NAIEP 10/91 P094

Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US020.

Darling Biomedical Library. Description.inscription: Poster text: AIDS does not discriminate. Anyone can get AIDS from sexual contact or sharing needles with an infected person. But we know how to prevent AIDS. Learn how to protect yourself. Call 1-800-541-AIDS.

Description.inscription: AIDS is a deadly disease caused by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus). To avoid infection through sex, don't have sex, or have sex only with a partner who isn't infected. An infected woman can pass HIV to her baby during pregnancy or when the baby is being born. HIV is spread by sharing needles...|~|Additional text: AIDS: facts for life

Title: Preocupándote del HIV no es suficiente. Más vale hacer algo
Description.note: Poster depicts the face of a pensive man.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US028.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Worrying about HIV is not sufficient. You have to do something|~|America responds to AIDS
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Si crees que estás a riesgo de estar infectado con el HIV, ahora es el momento de pensar en buscar la asesoría y hacerte examinar. Si tu resultado es positivo, trabaja junto con un médico para tomar las decisiones que serán las mehores para tí. Cuanto más rápido lo hagas, más le ayudará la atención médica. Consulta con un médico, con su departamento de salud o los otros centros locales para el SIDA. Llama al teléfono especial para el SIDA de su estado o zona local, o al teléfono nacional al 1-800-344-7432. Para las personas con impedimentos del oído, llama al 1-800-243-7889 (TTY). HIV es el virus que causa el SIDA.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Woman in sweater,
Description.note: Poster depicts a head and arms of a young woman wearing a sweater.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US030.
Description.inscription: Poster text: What have you got against a condom? The simple act of putting on a condom can save your life, if they're used properly and every time you have sex. For more information about AIDS and condoms, call 1-900-342-AIDS.
Alternate Title.inscribed: What have you got against a condom?|~|America responds to AIDS

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: How much do your children know about AIDS?
Description.note: Poster shows a group of children of different races.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US031.
Description.inscription: Poster text: How much do your children know about AIDS? Your children need an understanding of what it takes to be healthy. Schools can play an important role. If you'd like to know how you as a parent can be more involved in your school's curriculum, call 1-800-342-AIDS for information. For the hearing impaired, 1-800-AIDS-TTY. America responds to AIDS.

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: This is the way many people deal with HIV
Description.note: Poster depicts three people acting like the "see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil" monkeys. A man covers his eyes, a woman covers her ears, and another man covers his mouth.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US032.
Description.inscription: Poster text: This is the way many people deal with HIV. A lot of people don't think they have to worry about HIV. But the truth is, anyone can get HIV infection if they are sharing drug needles and syringes or having sex with an infected person. Call your State of local AIDS hotline. Or call the National AIDS Hotline at 1-800-342-AIDS. Call 1-800-243-7889 (TTY) for deaf access. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS. America Responds to AIDS.

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Condoms|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|Communication
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: If he doesn't have a condom, you just have to take a deep breath and tell him to go get one
Description.note: Poster depicts a woman sitting on a chair, with one foot on the seat of the chair.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US033.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: It's not the easiest thing in the world to say. But these days, you have to. If you're dating someone who doesn't like condoms, talk before having sex. Explain how you feel. Offer to help during the awkward moments. And if this doesn't work, ask yourself, is it worth the risk? For more information on condoms and AIDS, call 1-800-342-AIDS for answers you can count on. America responds to AIDS

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Don't just worry about HIV. Do something about it.
Description.note: Poster depicts the face of a worried-looking African-American man.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US034.
Description.inscription: Poster text: Don't just worry about HIV. Do something about it. If you think you are at risk for HIV infection, now's the time to consider counseling and testing. If you test positive, work with a doctor to make decisions that are right for you. The earlier this happens, the more medical care can help. Talk to a doctor, your health department, or other local AIDS resources. Call your State or local AIDS hotline, or the National AIDS Hotline at 1-800-342-AIDS. Call 1-800-243-7889 (TTY) for deaf access. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS. America responds to AIDS.

Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)|~|Sexually transmitted diseases|~|Adolescence|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|Coming of age|~|Gonorrhea|~|Death
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Some people think they come of age when they've been burnt by gonorrhea...
Description.note: Poster depicts a young African-American man standing against a chain-link fence.|~|Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US035.
Description.inscription: Some people think they come of age when they've been burnt by gonorrhea, but if they've been burnt by AIDS they may never come of age. To find out more about the relationship between AIDS and VD, call the National AIDS Hotline at 1-800-342-AIDS. The hotline for the hearing impaired is 1-800-AIDS-TTY. America Responds to AIDS

Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: If you cheat on your partner you could wind up with more than just a broken heart.
Description.note: Poster depicts an African-American man and woman holding hands.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US036.
Description.inscription: Poster text: If you cheat on your partner you could wind up with more than just a broken heart. With AIDS around, cheating on your partner could cheat you both out of your lives. AIDS is deadly. Even one encounter could infect you with the AIDS virus. So what started out as a harmless flirtation could turn into a deadly moment of truth. That's why it's important to know your partner. Because a broken heart is bad, but not as bad as a broken life. For more information about AIDS, call 1-800-342-AIDS. America responds to AIDS

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Hey! You know what? You can't get AIDS from...
Description.note: Poster consists of nine panels with colorful drawings depicting people, mostly children, doing things that don't transmit AIDS. The poster is targeted at children.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US037.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Hey! You know what? You can't get AIDS from: eating at restaurants, using toilets in public spaces, mosquito bites, giving someone a hug or kiss, sharing food with friends, playing on playgrounds, visiting someone who is sick with AIDS, going to the doctor, AIDS is not spread by things we touch!

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Opciones para las mujeres
Description.note: Poster lists four options for lessening the chance of AIDS transmission during sex. In order of decreasing effectiveness: using a condom and spermicide;  using a condom only; using a diaphragm and vaginal spermicide; and using spermicide only. Five women are pictured individually, one may be a doctor.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US038.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Options for women
Description.inscription: Poster text: Opciones para las mujeres, Qué puede hacer usted para protegerse del SIDA durante las relaciones sexuales? Absternerse o...

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Si tu has tenido sexo con dos personas...
Description.note: Poster is designed like an eye chart, with one very large word on the first line, three words in smaller type on the next line, etc. until the type is extremely tiny. The poster demonstrates the exponential nature of exposure to AIDS, as a person is susceptible to disease carried by people they have sex with, people they had had sex with before, etc.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US039.
Alternate Title.translated: If you have had sex with two people...
Description.inscription: Poster text: Si tu has tenido sexo con dos personas y esas dos personas cada una habia tenido sexo con otras dos personas y esas personas cada una habia tenido sexo con otras dos personas y... entonces es como si tú hubieras tenido sexo con 1,022 personas. Cualquiera pudo haberte infectado con el VIH - el virus que causa el SIDA. Para saber qué hacer ahora, llama gratis al servicio de información del VIH en Texas. 1-800-299-2437, Todas las llamadas son anónimas.|~|Translated poster text: If you have had sex with two people and each of those two people had had sex with two other people and each of those people had had sex with two other people... then it is as if you have had sex with 1,022 people. Any one of them could have been infected with HIV - the virus that causes AIDS...

Title: I have AIDS, please hug me
Description.note: Poster depicts a child's crayon drawing of a boy with his arms out. The text, "I have AIDS, please hug me, I can't make you sick" is written in crayon.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US040.
Description.inscription: I have AIDS, please hug me, I can't make you sick

Description.inscription: Poster text: Condomplation, There are a lot of things worth protecting. One of them is your life. Hero.

Title: AIDS : může mít podobu anděla
Description.note: Poster is a sketch of a nude female angel from the torso up. She is looking straight ahead. The word "AIDS" is inscribed at the top in large with lettering, with the "I" in red. The poster serves as a caution: AIDS can be contracted from anyone, even those that appear as wonderful as an angel.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Title: Women, girls and HIV/AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item TR001.|~|The poster is a long narrow poster with a 2005 calander printed on it. At the top of the poster there are five photographs of smiling faces of people of different races and ages. Under the pictures there is a red AIDS ribbon with several country flags on one end of the ribbon and the logo for Caribbean Epidemiology Centre (CAREC) PAHO/WHO on the other end of the ribbon. At the bottom of the poster there are logos for the three main organizations that have published and sponsored the poster.  The websites for the Caribbean Epidemiology Centre are: www.carec.org and www.catin.org.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Women and Girls are three to six time more likely than men to contract HIV.  Take the lead NOW.  Trust in Protection.Having sex with only one partner can be high-risk behavior -- because your partner's sexual behaviour.  Trust in Protection. Marriage or living with someone does not guarantee protection against HIV infection.  Take the lead NOW.  Trust in Protection.Women and girls are twice as likely as men to contract HIV from a single act of unprotected sex, yet they leave protection up to men.  Take the lead NOW.  Trust in Protection.Men, boys and social institutions can help improve the plight of women and girls when it comes to the AIDS epidemic.  Support protection for women.Education and economic empowerment can stop the spread of HIV.  Not chance.  Not luck. Trust in protection.|~|Additional poster text: Take the lead now.  Not chance, not luck.  Trust in protection.

Title: ...at home ...away [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT026.|~|The poster shows a cartoon man looking at snowglobe in his hand in which he is standing and looking at the Eiffel Tower.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text:  HIV transmission can take place either at home or while you are away.  Be prepared when you travel - think about the situations you may find yourself in.  Pack condoms and lube - they aren't available everywhere.  For more information for gay men who are traveling, check out the free booklet from your local AIDS council or visit www.afao.org.au.

They dipict ways that you can and the ways you cannot get HIV.  One of the pictures at the top of the poster under the "cannot get HIV" show two hands shaking with the caption handshakes.  One of the pictures at the bottom of the poster, under the "can get HIV" section is of durg paraphernalia.  The caption under that picture is "sharing HIV infected straws for snorting (sniffing) drugs.|~|Date on back of poster, 2003, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Title: Na cama comigo, só com preservativo. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster composed of three pictures arranged horizontally. With the first one showing three people in a bed with what seems wine glasses in hand. The logos for Harmony and ABRAÇO at the left and lower corners of the picture respectively. Second picture is basically the same but with a young woman in the bed holding a bunch of condoms inflated like balloons. A picture of photographer Tingo Brarens appears in the lower left corner of the poster. He is holding his camera, which has a condom over the lens.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO023.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: É altura de ensinar as crianças a viver num mundo com SIDA
Description.note: A childlike drawing done with crayolas shows a childish figure standing on a tuft of grass, over the word "eu" (me). There are two tufts of grass nearby over the words "pai" (father) and "mãe" (mother). The absence of any figures over those words suggests that the child has lost his or her parents to AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO024.
Alternate Title.translated: It is time to teach children to live in a world with AIDS.
Description.inscription: Algumas pessoas com SIDA, álem de terem o vírus, têm filhos. São milhares de crianças e adolescentes que ficam sem os pais, sem amor e sem recursos. Só não podemos permitir que eles percam a esperança.[Some people with AIDS, besides having the virus, also have children. There are thousands of children and adolescents that have no parents, no love, or resources. We can't allow them to lose hope.]

Title: Non si tratta di combattere i malati di AIDS. Si tratta di sconfiggere l'AIDS. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster shows a stack of papers with a sheet on top that describes the summary of measures taken by individual countries against international travelers about the screening test for HIV. A breif article about New Zealand is highlighted, cut out, and paperclip in front of it.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ072.
Alternate Title.translated: This is not to fight AIDS. This is to defeat AIDS
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: la giornata mondiale dell'AIDS non è una giornata festiva, ma di impegno solidale per ricordarci che il problema dell'AIDS è lungi dall'essere risolto. Chi emargina le persone sieropositive e i malati di AIDS crea dei confini illusori. Per fermare il virus dobbiamo farlo insieme. Per esempio, utilizzando sempre il preservativo nei nuovi rapporti sessuali. Proteggi il tuo prossimo come te stesso.|~|Translated poster text: World AIDS Day is not a public holiday, but a commitment of solidarity to remember that the problem of AIDS is far from resolved. The disease marginalizes people living with HIV and AIDS and it creates illusory boundaries. To stop the virus we must do it together. For example, by always using condoms in new sexual relationships. Protect your neighbor as yourself.

Title: Ne tournez pas le dos au SIDA [inscribed]
Description.note: Translated additional poster text:Each of us can help stop the spread of HIV and reduce the impact of AIDS. You do not need to be a senior scientist working on a remedy to make a difference. Protect yourself and others from HIV infection, welcome in your life someone living with HIV or simply talk about HIV and AIDS can help. Will you take action?Make a promise now www.worldaidscampaign.org|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA017.|~|The poster shows a woman wearing clothes of Indian tradition. She is sitting with her back toward the viewer.
Alternate Title.translated: Don't turn your back to HIV
Description.inscription: Additional poster text:Chacun d'entre nous peut contribuer à stopper la propagation du vih et à réduire l'impact du sida. Vous n'avez pas besoin d'être un scientifique de haut niveau travaillant sur un remde pour faire la différence. Vous protéger et protéger les autres de l'infection à vih, accueillir dans votre vie quelqu'un qui vit avec le vih ou encore simplement parler du vih et du sida peuvent aider. Allez-vous passer à l'action?Faites une promesse dès maintenant sur www.worldaidscampaign.org

Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|World AIDS Day|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign|~|Ford Foundation
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Asume el liderazgo. [inscribed]
Description.note: Image of an AIDS ribbon being placed in a ballot box.  Poster suggests that society needs to take the lead in AIDS/HIV prevention and control and to not wait for politicians to do things.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA018.
Alternate Title.translated: Take the lead.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Los lideres mundiales prometieron proporcionar, para el año 2010, acceso universal a la prevención y apoyo relacionados con el VIH.  A pesar de ello, más personas que nunca se están infectando por el VIH y sólo una pequeña parte de quienes necesitan tratamiento lo reciben. Es hora de exigir responsabilidades a nuestros líderes. Asume el liderazgo. Exigo acción.  Detén el SIDA.  Mantén la promesa.|~|Translated additional poster text: The world leaders pledged to provide, by 2010, universal access to prevention and HIV support. However, more people than ever are becoming infected with HIV and only a small part of those who need treatment receive it. It's time to demand accountability from our leaders. Take the Lead. Demands action. Stop AIDS. Keep the Promise.

Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign|~|Ford Foundation
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Asume el liderazgo. [inscribed]
Description.note: On a purple background, four white silhouettes reaching for a red ribbon.  One silhouette has jumped and grabbed the ribbon.  The poster suggests that in order to prevent HIV and AIDS, one must take a leadership role and take initiative instead of waiting for others to do it.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA019.
Alternate Title.translated: Take the lead.
Description.inscription: Translated additional poster text: Take the Lead. To achieve universal access to prevention, treatment, care and support related to HIV by the year 2010, leadership is needed at all levels. Leadership begins in schools and in families, in places of work and worship. Be a leader wherever you are. Stop AIDS. Keep the Promise.|~|Additional poster text: Para lograr el acceso universal a la prevención, tratamiento, atención y apoyo relacionados con el VIH para el año 2010, se necesita liderazgo en todos niveles.  El liderazgo empieza en las escuelas y en las familias, en los lugares de trabajo y de culto.  Sé un lider alli donde estés.  Detén el SIDA.  Mantén la promesa.

Title: Deliver [inscribed]
Description.note: Descriptive note: Poster emphasizing on universal access for prevention, treatment, care and support for AIDS. Also indicating lack of access to treatments for women and children.|~|Poster shows a hand writing with a red ribbon instead of pen on AIDS|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA020.
Description.inscription: ... the urgent need to scale up significantly towards the goal of universal access to comprehensive pervention programmes, treatment, care and support by 2010.|~|Additional poster text: At the beginning of 2008, one-third of peopLe in low and middle income countries needing antiretroviraL treatment and one-third of women requiring drugs to prevent transmission of HIV to their children received them. But to scaLe up towards universaL access to HIV prevention, treatment, care and support by 2010, Leaders must deliver now

Subject.conceptTopic: World AIDS Day|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control|~|HIV infections--Treatment
Personal or Corporate Publisher.publishe: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign|~|Ford Foundation
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: S'activer [inscribed]
Description.note: The poster shows a picture of a hand holding a ribbon like a pen writing the name Ali.|~|Translated additional poster text: In early 2008, only one third of those needing antiretroviral treatment in countries with low or middle income and only one third of women who need to receive medicines to prevent HIV transmission to their children . But to achieve the goals of universal access to prevention, treatment and care set for 2010, leaders must now be activated.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA021.
Alternate Title.translated: Activate
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Début 2008, seulement un tiers des personnes nécessitant des traitements antirétroviraux dans les pays a revenus faibles ou intermédiaires et seulement un tiers des femmes ayant besoin de médicaments pour empêcher la transmission du VIH a leurs enfants les recevaient. Mais pour atteindre les objectifs d'accès universel a la prévention, au traitement et aux soins fixés pour l'horizon 2010, les dirigeants doivent s'activer maintenant.

Title: Lead: On World AIDS Day, individuats from around the world come together to lead the response to AlDS. Each of us has something unique to contribute from standing up against stigma and discrimination to educating ourselves about HIV prevention, from knowing our status to learning more about the commitments our leaders have made. Our voices can make a difference [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA022.|~|Poster presents a group of men, women and children are helping each other to build a big red ribbon with red rectangles. Title: Mener [inscribed]
Description.note: Translated additional poster text:On the occasion of World AIDS Day, people around the world gather to carry the response against AIDS. We all have something unique to bring:oppose stigma and discrimination, educate themselves on ways of prevention against HIV, or about the commitments our leaders have made. Our voice can make a difference.Stop AIDS. Keep the Promise. For more information, visit:www.worldaidscampaign.org|~|The poster shows a picture of a group of men and women performing different things, and there are two men climbing on a ladder.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA023.
Alternate Title.translated: Lead
Description.inscription: Additional poster text:A l‘occasion de la journée mondiale sida, des personnes du monde entier se rassemblent pour mener la riposte contre le sida. Nous avons tous quelque chose d’unique a apportér:s’opposer à la stigmatisation et à la discrimination, s’éduquer sur les modes de prévention contre le VIH, ou s’informer sur les engagements que nos dirigeants ont pris. Notre voix peut faire la différence.Stop SIDA. Tenez la promesse. Pour plus d’informations, consultez le site:www.worldaidscampaign.org

Subject.conceptTopic: World AIDS Day|~|Social advocacy|~|AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|Awareness|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|AIDS (Disease)--Political aspects|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control|~|HIV infections--Social aspects
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Stop Sida. Tenons notre Promesse. [inscribed]
Description.note: Translated additional poster text: The world has promised to stop AIDS by 2015. What will you do?The Millennium Development Goal on AIDS is to halt the spread of AIDS and begin to reverse the trend by 2015. To achieve this goal, promises were made and commitments were made at individual, community and national levels. Engage in the Global Campaign against AIDS to ensure that these promises are kept. For details, visit www.worldaidscampaign.org|~|The poster shows a picture of people who are doing a demonstration againt AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA024.
Alternate Title.translated: Stop Aids. Keep our promise
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Le monde a promis de stopper le SIDA d'ici 2015. Que ferez-vous?L'objectif du Millénaire relatif au SIDA vise à stopper Ia propagation du SIDA et à commencer à inverser Ia tendance d'ici 2015. Pour atteindre cet objectif, des promesses ont été faites et des engagements ont été pris au niveau individuel, communautaire et national. Engagez-vous dans Ia Campagne Mondiale contre le SIDA pour vous assurer que ces promesses sont tenues. Pour plus de détails, rendez-vous sur www.worldaidscampaign.org

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Empower [inscribed]
Description.note: Description note: the poster shows the figures of a woman a boy and a girl, which are silhouetted in white on a green background. The children are coloring on paper with red AIDS ribbons.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA025.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: The response to AIDS depends on the strength of individuals and communities. To halt the epidemic, it is essential to eliminate the social and economic inequalities and injustices that fuel its spread. Empowering individuals and communities to respond to AIDS is a critical and a fundamental part of respecting and promoting their human rights.|~|Additional poster text: Stop AIDS. keep the promise.

Subject.conceptTopic: Social advocacy|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control|~|HIV infections--Social aspects
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Responsabiliser [inscribed]
Description.note: Translated additional poster text: The response to AIDS depends on the strength of individuals and communities. To stop the epidemic, it is essential to eliminate inequalities and social and economic injustices that feed its growth. Empowering individuals and communities to deal with AIDS is a critical and fundamental respect, promotion and enhancement of their human rights. Stop AIDS, keep the promise. To obtain more information, consult the website: www.worldaidscampaign.org.|~|The poster shows a picture of a woman with a boy and a girl, it looks like she is teaching them, both the boy and the girl are writing with an AIDS ribbon on a peice of paper.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA026.
Alternate Title.translated: Empowerment
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: La riposte au sida dépend de la force des individus et des communautés. Pour arrêter l'épidémie, il est essentiel d'éliminer les inégalités et injustices sociales et économiques qui nourissent sa progression. Responsabiliser les individus et les communautés pour faire face au sida est un élément critique et fondamental du respect, de la promotion et de la valorisation de leurs droits humains. Stop SIDA. Tenez la promesse. Pour plus d'informations, consultez le site: www.worldaidscampaign.org.

Mantén la promesa.|~|Translated additional poster text:  In 2006, 4.3 million people became infected with HIV, a figure larger than any other year. The most affected people are striving to change that trend. Follow his example. Be a leader. Stop AIDS. Keep the Promise.

Description.inscription: Additional poster text:The PartNer Assistance Program (PNAP) can help you let your sex and needle sharing partners know they may be at risk for HIV. It's important to let your partners know so they can: get an HIV test. get the health care they need. learn how to protect themselves and other from HIV. PNAP is free and confidential! You decide how you want to use the program!PNAP Helps People with HIV

Title: ADAP plus [inscribed]
Description.note: There are two other versions of this poster with the same title: [Spanish] and [French].|~|Poster is divided in two halves. The left part depicts racially mixed faces of the people placed in the heart shaped frame. The background color of the left half is green. The right part depicts shape of plus symbol with inscription: “ADAP plus”. The background color of the right half is blue. Also poster provides telephone number, where information about medications, medical and home care, and insurance coverage can be found.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US083.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: If you or someone you love is HIV + you need to know about ADAP plus; ADAP Plus is a program that helps people get medications, medical care, home care -- and now, the program can even help with insurance coverage. Best of all, it's free; State of New York. Department of Health; 1-800-542-2437.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: They've been hit. With AIDS, too [inscribed]
Description.note: Additional poster text: Professional models.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US084.|~|Poster shows five black-and-white photographs of women at different ages and of different races. All women look sad, scared or worried. One of the women is crying. Three others have bruises on their faces. Two of the women hold their kids and look worried probably about the children and their future. Also poster provides telephone number, where abused and infected women can get help.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: A partner who hits you may insist on having unprotected sex with you. If he has had sex with someone else or if he has shot drugs, he might be putting you at risk for HIV, the virus that causes AIDS; Get help. Call 1-800-942-6906 (English), 1-800-942-6908 (Spanish), 24 hours, 7 days a week, New York State Office for the Prevention of Domestic Violence and New York State Department of Health.

Title: Age won't protect you from AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: There are three other versions of this poster: [male] and [female] versions with the same title and [Spanish] version.|~|Poster depicts head of a black woman at her 50-60th. Also poster provides telephone number, where information and other related services can be found. The background color of the poster is lilac.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US085.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: More than 8,000 New Yorkers over 50 years old have been diagnosed with AIDS; HIV prevention is a lifelong job; To learn more, call 1-800-541-AIDS; It's not how old are you -- it's what you do that matters.|~|Additional poster text: 9539 New York State Department of Health.

Title: Nada mejor que el pecho a menos que usted tenga el VIH [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US089.|~|Poster shows four identical pictures of a women breast feeding an infant. The pictures each have a different color hue.
Alternate Title.translated: Nothing better than brestfeeding unless you have HIV
Description.inscription: Translated poster text: If you are pregnant or plan to have a child, you should be tested for HIV, the AIDS virus. If you are infected, your baby may be born infected ... or contract the infection through your milk.|~|Additional poster text: Si usted está embarazada o piensa tener un hijo, debería someterse a la prueba para detectar el VIH, el virus del SIDA. Si usted está infectada, su bebé podría nacer infectado... o contraer la infección a través de su leche.

Title: SIDA también las ha golpeado. Pide ayuda [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster has 5 black and white photos showing the faces of abused women (some with children) with various ages and ethnicities.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US093.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS has also beaten them. Ask for help
Description.inscription: Translated poster text: If your companion abuses you, surely he will insist on having sexual relations without precautions. If he had sexual contact with another person or has injected drugs, you are exposed to the danger of contracting HIV, the virus causing AIDS. Call... 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Office for the Prevention of Domestic Violence New York State Department of Health and the State of New York.|~|Translated poster text: professional models|~|Additional poster text: Si tu compañero te maltrata, seguramente también insiste en tener relaciones sexuales sin tomar precauciones. Si él tuvo contacto sexual con alguna otra persona o se inyectó drogas, te expone al peligro de contraer el VIH, el virus causante del SIDA.Llama al 1-800-942-6906 (Inglés) 1-800-942-6908 (Español). Las 24 horas del día, los 7 días de la semana. Oficina para la Prevención de la Violencia Doméstica del Estado de Nueva York y Departamento de Salud del Estado de Nueva York.|~|Additional poster text: "Modelos profesionales" and "9265"
